[[File:Aktion Saybusch 1940.jpg|thumb|right|320px|''Aktion Saybusch'', 24 September 1940. Expelled Poles await transport at a railway crossing (in this photo, some members of the 129 families deported from the village of [[Sól, Silesian Voivodeship|Dolna Sól]]).{{sfn|Machcewicz|2010}}]] '''Action Saybusch''' ({{lang-de|Aktion Saybusch}}, {{lang-pl|Akcja Żywiec}}) was the mass expulsion of some 18,000–20,000 ethnic [[Poles]] from the territory of [[Żywiec County]] in Polish [[Silesia]], conducted by the [[Wehrmacht]] and [[Ordnungspolizei#Police Battalions|German police]] during the German [[occupation of Poland]] in World War II. The main purpose of the [[Ethnic cleansing|forcible displacement]] of [[Poles|Polish nationals]] was to create space for ethnically German colonists from across Eastern Europe, after the annexation of western [[Poland]] into the [[Third Reich]] in 1939.<ref name="fronda.pl">{{cite web | url=http://www.fronda.pl/news/czytaj/tytul/saybusch_aktion_-_jak_hitler_budowal_raj_dla_swoich_chlopow_15558 | title=Saybusch Aktion - jak Hitler budował raj dla swoich chłopów | publisher=Redakcja ''Fronda.pl'' | work=OBEP [[Institute of National Remembrance]], Katowice | date=20 September 2011 | accessdate=May 5, 2012 | author=Mirosław Sikora | language=Polish}}</ref>
The Action was part of the Adolf Hitler's plan known as [[Lebensraum]] which involved Germanization of all [[Polish areas annexed by Nazi Germany|Polish areas]] west of the territory allocated to the [[General Government]]. The name of the Action came from the [[German language|German]] name of the city of [[Żywiec]] – Saybusch.<ref name="fronda.pl" /> Displacements of the Poles from [[Żywiec]] and surrounding villages and towns was led by the occupation authorities under ''{{nobreak|SS-Obersturmbannführer}}'' [[Fritz Arlt]], who replaced [[Bruno Müller (Nazi)|Bruno Müller]] from RKF.<ref name="Toppe">{{cite book | title=Militär und Kriegsvölkerrecht: Rechtsnorm, Fachdiskurs und Kriegspraxis in Deutschland 1899-1940 | publisher=Oldenbourg Wissenschaftsverlag | author=Andreas Toppe | year=2008 | pages=398– | isbn=978-3-486-58206-2}}</ref><ref name="Sikora" />
''Aktion Saybusch'' lasted from September to December 1940, with some 3,200 [[Volksdeutsche]] brought in ''[[Heim ins Reich]]'' (Home into the Empire) from Romanian [[Bukovina]]. The process of expulsions continued thereafter. In total, between 1940 and 1944, around 50,000 Poles were forcibly removed from the region and replaced with about 4,000 settlers from Eastern Galicia and Volhynia who were given new [[Latifundium|latifundia]]. Before the [[Operation Barbarossa|German attack on the Soviet Union]], their transfer was agreed upon by both invaders at the [[Gestapo–NKVD Conferences]]. The expulsions from eastern [[Silesia]] were the direct responsibility of the ''{{nobreak|[[SS]]-[[Obergruppenführer]]}}'' [[Erich von dem Bach-Zelewski]], who was also responsible for instigating them.{{sfn|Machcewicz|2010}}<ref name="Sikora" />
==Course of the expulsions== [[File:Aktion Saybusch (Akcja Zywiec) 1940.jpg|thumb|right|Women awaiting transport during Action Saybusch, 24 September 1940]] {{main|Heim ins Reich}} In December 1939, the German police conducted a population census in the region. Over 99 percent of the locals declared Polish nationality. Analysis of the census figures set the stage for the mass deportations across [[Upper Silesia]], which was decided in July 1940. Some believe that Polish Jews were not a part of this ''Aktion''.{{sfn|Machcewicz|2010|loc=''Wśród wysiedlonych nie mogło być osób narodowości żydowskiej.'' There could have been no people of Jewish nationality among the deportees.}} On the other hand, the Holocaust historian [[Christopher R. Browning]] wrote that Jews had to have been an integral part of it. The local Germans "had not diligently carried out the identification and seizure of Polish activists and intelligentsia and thus were not eager to report the actual number of Jews deported."{{sfn|Browning|2007}} For example, the Jewish families from the [[:pl:Zabłocie (Żywiec)|Zabłocie district]] of Żywiec were transported to a [[Jewish ghettos in German-occupied Poland|transit ghetto and labour camp]] in [[Sucha Beskidzka]] in the spring of 1941,<ref>{{citation |title=Jewish history of Zabłocie district of Żywiec |author=Andrzej Tepper |publisher=Kirkuty - cmentarze żydowskie w Polsce - Jewish cemeteries in Poland |url=http://www.kirkuty.xip.pl/zywiec.htm |language=pl |year=2015 |quote=''Liczba Żydów zamieszkujących Zabłocie, Isep i Sporysz - obecnie dzielnice Żywca - w 1938 roku doszła do dziewięciuset.'' The number of Jews living in Zabłocie, Isep and Sporysz neighborhoods of Żywiec reached 900 by 1938.}}</ref> and in 1942 sent aboard [[Holocaust trains]] to [[Auschwitz]].<ref>{{citation |title=Jewish history of Sucha Beskidzka |author=[[Virtual Shtetl]] |publisher=[[POLIN Museum of the History of Polish Jews]] |url=http://www.sztetl.org.pl:80/en/article/sucha-beskidzka/5,history/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141106044005/http://www.sztetl.org.pl:80/en/article/sucha-beskidzka/5,history/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2014-11-06 |chapter=Deportations to Auschwitz-Birkenau |chapter-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141106044015/http://www.sztetl.org.pl:80/en/article/sucha-beskidzka/5,history/?action=view&page=5 |via=Internet Archive |year=2014}}</ref> Everything was carefully prepared by the German occupation authorities, with schedules for the Polish train transports, food rations, and a group of Gestapo functionaries who spoke Polish. The cost of the operation estimated at about 300,000 [[German Reichsmark|Marks]] was to be paid by the captives themselves. The Action began simultaneously at different locations on September 22, 1940 at 5 in the morning. The police and army units surrounded Polish settlements and entered individual homes ordering farmers to get out within 20 minutes. Eye-witness Helena Szatanikowa remarked that all instructions came from a warrant printed in Polish.{{sfn|Machcewicz|2010}} Residents were requested to turn in all money and valuables. They were allowed to take with them only clothing and food, leaving behind everything else including livestock. They were marched and trucked to the so-called transit points in nearby towns of Żywiec, [[Rajcza]], [[Sucha Beskidzka]], [[Końskie]] and others. Meanwhile, the new Germanic settlers were already waiting at the distribution centers set up in [[Bogumin]] and [[Cieszyn]]. The Poles were subjected to selection, and separated into those "racially valuable" (for preferential treatment) and the rest, including women and children. Groups of young men were gathered for slave labor in Germany. According to German law all captives were to be supplied with necessities for 14 days; however, in practice they were stripped of the remnants of their own belongings in the process of luggage and body searches.{{sfn|Machcewicz|2010}}<ref name="nsik.com">{{cite web | url=http://www.nsik.com.pl/archiwum/95/a17.html | title=Pokrzywdzeni... | publisher=''Nad Sołą i Koszarawą'' No. 16 (95), year 5 | work=Trybuna, C/D/N | date=15 August 2002 | accessdate=May 5, 2012 | author=Malwina Palińska | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304073923/http://www.nsik.com.pl/archiwum/95/a17.html | archive-date=2016-03-04 | dead-url=yes | df= }}</ref> [[File:Expulsion of Poles from Żywiec County 01.jpg|thumb|Polish families carrying allowable possessions board deportation train]]
The assembly points at railway stations held each time about 1,000 Polish people; who were split into groups of 40 in line with already numbered rail cars. Each transport was usually sent separately, first to a railway junction in [[Łódź]] (for further selection), and from there, to previously chosen locations across the [[General Government]] (''Generalgouvernement''). Poles were delivered to towns and villages in the vicinity of [[Biłgoraj]], [[Wadowice]], [[Radzymin]], [[Łuków]], and to the [[Lublin]] and [[Kielce]] [[governorate]]s (see, the [[Lublin Reservation]] organized since October 1939), where they were dropped off alone without any help. Moreover, the Germans had warned the local population that the arriving deportees were criminals, thus further worsening their plight. They were met with fear and only reluctant acceptance at their destinations. Many died during transport. Others were forced to beg. The whole displacement action was conducted by the ''Polizei-Battalion No. 82'' (under Kegel) and ''Battalion No. 83'' (under [[Eugen Seim]], stationed in [[Jeleśnia]]) with approximately 500 soldiers as well as numerous SS, RKF and NSDAP functionaries including ''Katowice'' Gestapo officers.{{sfn|Machcewicz|2010}}<ref name="Sikora">{{cite web | url=http://www.radiomaryja.pl/artykuly.php?id=100635 | title="Aktion Saybusch" na Żywiecczyźnie | publisher=[[Institute of National Remembrance]], [[Katowice]] | work=Reprinted by Nasz Dziennik | date=16 September 2009 | accessdate=May 5, 2012 | author=Mirosław Sikora}}</ref> {{See also|Expulsion of Poles by Nazi Germany|Polenlager}}
==The settlers== Abandoned Polish houses were cleaned and washed by forced laborers, mostly Jewish captives and some remaining Poles, who were later employed by the new farm-owners. Sheds deemed unsanitary were torn down. The department prepared swastika flags and portraits of Hitler to be placed at farms declared ready for occupation by the new Germans. Despite the Nazi propaganda campaign painting a rosy picture of their opulent future, the new hosts were not given the best of lands, which were reserved for the ''[[Reichsdeutsche]]'' who had served in the Wehrmacht. Many settlers were disappointed with the simple wooden cottages they were told to move into, and poor quality farmland.<ref name="fronda.pl" /><ref name="nsik.com" /> The ''[[Wartheland]]'' [[Nazi Party#Nazi Party Gaue|''Gaue'' officials]] on their part, lamented the newcomers' cultural backwardness in comparison with most Poles, and their inability to speak proper German. The new settlers were put under permanent police surveillance.<ref name="projectinposterum">{{cite journal |url=http://www.projectinposterum.org/docs/lucas2.htm |title=Chapter IV. Germanization |publisher=Hippocrene Books |work=Did the Children Cry? Hitler's War against Jewish and Polish Children, 1939-1945 |year=2001 |author=[[Richard C. Lukas]] |id=Project InPosterum. Preserving the Past for the Future}}</ref> [[File:Expulsion of Poles from Żywiec County 02.jpg|thumb|Expulsion of the Polish women with children from the Żywiec County]]
''Aktion Saybusch'' officially ended on December 12, 1940, although the last transport (out of the total number of 19) was dispatched as late as January 31, 1941. On top of the 18,000–20,000 deportees sent across [[General Government|the border]], some 8,000 Poles employed in local industries were moved away from their homes. It was a pilot project meant to be followed by similar actions, but in March 1941 ''SS-Obergruppenführer'' [[Hans Frank]], Governor of General Government, objected to further overcrowding of his district.{{sfn|Machcewicz|2010}} As a result, from 1942 on, Polish deportees were placed with other farmers in the poorest villages within the same territory of Silesia (''Interne Umsiedlung''), or sent to one of the new 23 camps called ''[[Polenlager]]'', created especially for that purpose. By the end of war, about 50,000 Polish nationals were displaced from Żywiec and the surrounding area, nearly one-third of its population. In ''Polenlagers'', further selections were carried out, including racial abductions of children from their parents, who after verification were sent to ''[[Lebensborn]]'' centers for Germanization. The displaced Polish farmers who returned to their homes in 1945 often found buildings razed or destroyed and everything else stolen by the settlers escaping the Soviet advance.{{sfn|Machcewicz|2010}}<ref name="Sikora" />
==IPN investigation== In the early 1990s, Action Saybusch was investigated by the Commission for the Prosecution of Crimes Against the Polish Nation at the [[Institute of National Remembrance]] in [[Katowice]] followed by a formal inquiry initiated in 1998 by Senator Władysław Bułka.<ref name="nsik.com" /> After a series of announcements in the press, some 1,000 persons contacted IPN with personally collected data and supplementary materials, revealing the identities of many displaced families. According to Ewa Koj from IPN most living victims had already been interviewed. The investigation was limited by their advancing age and had to be discontinued on legal grounds.<ref name="nsik.com" /> However, it was followed by a broad exhibit of documents and photographs collected in the process, and presented in many regional cities and towns including Katowice, Żywiec, [[Bielsko-Biała]] and others. The Nazi perpetrators of ethnic cleansing had already been sentenced during the [[Nuremberg trials]]. The IPN announced that discussing matters of war compensation was not within their mandate, which some living victims found disappointing.<ref name="ipn.gov.pl-2">{{cite journal |url=http://www.ipn.gov.pl/portal/pl/2/16349/Konferencja_naukowa_i_wystawa_Aktion_Saybusch_Wysiedlenia_mieszkancow_Zywiecczyz.html |title=Aktion Saybusch. Wysiedlenia mieszkańców Żywiecczyzny przez okupanta niemieckiego 1940–1941 |location=Katowice |publisher=[[Instytut Pamięci Narodowej]] |work=Konferencja naukowa "Aktion Saybusch" |date=13 May 2011 |accessdate=May 5, 2012}}</ref><ref name="ipn.gov.pl-1">{{cite web | url=http://www.ipn.gov.pl/portal/pl/2/17323/Prezentacja_wystawy_Aktion_Saybusch_Wysiedlenie_mieszkancow_Zywiecczyzny_przez_o.html?search=66823379 | title=Prezentacja wystawy "Aktion Saybusch. Wysiedlenie mieszkańców Żywiecczyzny przez okupanta niemieckiego 1940–1941" – Bielsko-Biała, 28 września – 7 października 2011 | publisher=[[Instytut Pamięci Narodowej]] | work=Aktualności | date=2011 | accessdate=May 5, 2012 | language=Polish}}</ref><ref name="beskidmaly.pl">{{cite web | url=http://www.beskidmaly.pl/artpokaz.php?id=4 | title=Aktion Saybusch. Wysiedlenie mieszkańców Żywiecczyzny przez okupanta niemieckiego 1940-1941 | publisher=Agencja Turystyki Beskidzkiej | work=Instytut Pamięci Narodowej o. Katowice. Wystawa | date=11 January 2011 | accessdate=May 5, 2012 | language=Polish}}</ref><ref name="beskidzywiecki.bl">{{cite web | url=http://beskidzywiecki.bloog.pl/id,6435502,title,Wysiedleni,index.html?_ticrsn=3&ticaid=6e653 | title=Wysiedleni. Ekspozycja w żywieckim muzeum | publisher=[[Super-nowa.pl]] | work=Beskid Żywiecki. Turystyka | date=27 September 2010 | accessdate=May 5, 2012 | language=Polish}}</ref><ref name="zywiecczyzna">{{cite web | url=http://www.zywiecczyzna.pl/wegierska/szczegoly.php?11799 | title=Aktion Saybusch | publisher=Zywiecczyzna.pl | work=Węgierska-Górka: Wystawy | date=4 February 2011 | accessdate=May 5, 2012 | author=OPG WG}}</ref>

{{refimprove|date=December 2015}}
The '''Anti-Corruption Resource Centre (U4)''' was established in 2002 and is targeted at donor practitioners who wish to effectively address corruption challenges in their work. U4 offers focused research products and a rich array of online resources.
The Anti-Corruption Resource Centre is based at the [[Chr. Michelsen Institute]] in Bergen, Norway. The Resource Centre works in collaboration with [[Transparency International]], Tiri and many other international organisations and NGOs.
The international development agencies of the following countries are the current U4 Partners:
* UK: [[Department for International Development]] (DFID) * Norway: [[Norwegian Agency for Development Cooperation]] (Norad) * Sweden: [[Swedish International Development Cooperation Agency]] (Sida) * Germany: [[Deutsche Gesellschaft für Technische Zusammenarbeit]] (GTZ), BMZ, KfW * The Netherlands: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs * Canada: [[Canadian International Development Agency]] (CIDA)
''[The Resource centre was previously referred to as the 'Utstein Anti-Corruption Resource Centre', as it originally stems from the now defunct 'Utstein' collaboration started in 1999 between the ministers of international development of the UK, Norway, The Netherlands, and Germany]''
== Theme pages developed for a donor audience ==
* '''UN Convention against Corruption:''' A one-stop site on the UNCAC for development practitioners. Includes briefing documents, Expert Answers, examples of donor support for implementation, and selected literature. * '''Public Financial Management:''' Issue pages on corruption and direct budget support, corruption and revenue administration, and corruption and the budget process. * '''Corruption in the Health Sector:''' A comprehensive overview of the relevant issues (causes and consequences, financial resources management, medical supplies, health worker / patient interaction, salaries, and more). * '''Corruption in the Education Sector:''' Resources on the challenges posed by corruption in the education sector with a focus on development co-operation and implementation of aid projects. * '''Corruption in Emergencies:''' Includes resources on risk mapping, the role of the media, selected literature, and more. Soon available: Corruption and procurement in emergencies. * '''Donor Coordination:''' Case studies, country- and donor factors, possibilities and practicalities, further resources, etc. * '''Knowledge Management for Anti-Corruption:''' Summary note looking at the problems, perspectives and prospects. Links to further resources and background materials. * '''African Anti-Corruption Commissions:''' Studies of ACCs in five African countries (Ghana, Uganda, Tanzania, Malawi and Zambia). * '''Anti-Corruption Conventions:''' An overview of conventions, their scope and powers. *''' Public Expenditure Tracking Surveys:''' Can PETS be a tool for tackling corruption? * '''Political Corruption:''' Definitions, cases, the challenges and options, and a literature overview.
== Selected literature database ==
An updated collection of direct links to the most relevant anti-corruption readings for practitioners. This includes brief descriptions of more than 300 titles.
== Expert Answers ==
More than 100 previous expert answers to U4 Partner staff's corruption-related questions are available publicly online for anyone to read, and more new answers are added regularly. This service is oberated by [[Transparency International]]’s secretariat in Berlin.
==External links== *[http://www.u4.no Anti-Corruption Resource Centre (U4)]

{{Social Christianity}} {{African American topics sidebar|right}} {{Black Power sidebar}} '''Black theology''', or '''Black liberation theology''', refers to a theological perspective which originated among African American seminarians and scholars, and in some [[black church]]es in the [[United States]] and later in other parts of the world. It contextualizes [[Christianity]] in an attempt to help those of African descent overcome oppression. It especially focuses on the [[injustice]]s committed against [[African American]]s and black [[South African]]s during [[Jim Crow laws|American segregation]] and [[Apartheid in South Africa|apartheid]], respectively. Black theology seeks to liberate non-white people from multiple forms of political, social, economic, and religious subjugation and views [[Christian theology]] as a theology of liberation—"a rational study of the being of God in the world in light of the existential situation of an oppressed community, relating the forces of liberation to the essence of the Gospel, which is [[Jesus|Jesus Christ]]," writes [[James H. Cone]], one of the original advocates of the perspective. Black theology mixes [[Christianity]] with questions of [[civil rights]], particularly raised by the [[Black Power movement]] and the [[Black Consciousness Movement]]. Further, Black theology has led the way and contributed to the discussion, and conclusion, that all theology is contextual - even what is known as [[systematic theology]]. == Development == Modern American origins of contemporary Black theology can be traced to July 31, 1966, when an ad hoc group of 51 concerned clergy, calling themselves the National Committee of Negro Churchmen (NCNC), bought a full page ad in ''[[The New York Times]]'' to publish their "Black Power Statement," which proposed a more aggressive approach to combating racism using the [[Bible]] for inspiration.{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=88552254&ft=1&f=1001|title=A Closer Look at Black Liberation Theology|last=Hagerty|first=Barbara Bradley|date=March 18, 2008|publisher=NPR}} In American history, ideas of [[Race and ethnicity in the United States|race]] and [[Slavery in the United States|slavery]] were supported by many Christians from particular readings of the Bible.{{cite web|first=Terry|last=Matthews|url=http://www.wfu.edu/~matthetl/perspectives/twentyseven.html|title=A Black Theology of Liberation|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080430193355/http://www.wfu.edu/~matthetl/perspectives/twentyseven.html |archive-date=April 30, 2008}} The [[Southern Baptist Convention]] supported slavery and slaveholders; it was not until June 20, 1995 that the formal [[Southern Baptist Convention#Recent history|Declaration of Repentance]] was adopted. This non-binding resolution declared that racism, in all its forms, is deplorable" and "lamented on a national scale and is also repudiated in history as an act of evil from which a continued bitter harvest unfortunately is reaped." The convention offered an apology for "condoning and/or perpetuating individual and systemic racism in our lifetime" and repentance for "racism of which many have been guilty, whether consciously or unconsciously.{{cite journal|title=SBC renounces racist past|journal=Christian Century|date=July 5, 1995|volume=112|issue=21|pages=671–672}} Christianity is associated with racism. Yet Christ; the forerunner of christian behavior professed individuality and in living testimony is demonized for the pursuit of individually targeted sanctuary. Therefore, there must then be a dialogue regarding the implications of racism in today's society and to what extent historical, intellectual, social factors affect the plight of the Black community. Cone relates that, once upon a time it was acceptable to lynch a Black man by hanging him from the tree; but today's economics destroy him by crowding many into a ghetto and letting filth and despair (created by themselves) put final touch on a coveted death." Black theology deals primarily with the African-American community to make Christianity real for Blacks. It explains Christianity as a matter of liberation here and now, rather than in an afterlife. The goal of Black theology is not for special treatment. Instead, "All Black theologians are asking for is for freedom and justice. No more, and no less. In asking for this, the Black theologians, turn to scripture as the sanction for their demand. The Psalmist writes for instance, "If God is going to see righteousness established in the land, he himself must be particularly active as "the helper of the fatherless" (Psalm 10:14) to "deliver the needy when he crieth; and the poor that hath no helper" (Psalm 72:12). Black theology would eventually develop outside of the United States to the United Kingdom and parts of Africa, especially addressing apartheid in South Africa. == Black theology in the United States == {{main|James Hal Cone}} [[James Hal Cone|James Cone]] first addressed this theology after [[Malcolm X]]'s proclamation in the 1950s against Christianity being taught as "a white man's religion".{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/thisfarbyfaith/people/james_cone.html|title=James Cone|publisher=[[Public Broadcasting Service|PBS]]}} According to Black religion expert Jonathan Walton:
James Cone believed that the New Testament revealed Jesus as one who identified with those suffering under oppression, the socially marginalized and the cultural outcasts. And since the socially constructed categories of race in America (i.e., whiteness and blackness) had come to culturally signify dominance (whiteness) and oppression (blackness), from a theological perspective, Cone argued that Jesus reveals himself as black in order to disrupt and dismantle white oppression.{{cite web|last=Posner|first=Sarah|url=http://www.salon.com/2008/05/03/black_church/ |title=Wright's theology not 'new or radical'|publisher=[[Salon (website)|Salon]]|date=May 3, 2005}}
Black theology contends that dominant cultures have corrupted Christianity, and the result is a mainstream faith-based empire that serves its own interests, not God's. Black theology asks whose side should God be on—the side of the oppressed or the side of the oppressors. If God values justice over victimization, then God desires that all oppressed people should be liberated. According to Cone, if God is not just, if God does not desire justice, then God needs to be done away with. Liberation from a false god who privileges whites, and the realization of an alternative and true God who desires the empowerment of the oppressed through self-definition, self-affirmation, and self-determination is the core of Black theology.{{cite book|last=Cone|first=James H. |title=A Black Theology of Liberation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mqfsPwxuLrEC|year=2010|publisher=Orbis Books|location=Maryknoll, NY|isbn=978-1-60833-036-2|page=64-67}} === On God and Jesus Christ === Intricate and largely philosophical views of God are largely ignored in preference for the concerns of the oppressed. The Old Testament God of Moses freeing the ancient Hebrews from Egyptian rulers was the central theme of African American popular religion, as well as abolitionists like [[Harriet Tubman]].{{cite book|last=Feiler|first=Bruce|year=2009|title=America's prophet: how the story of Moses shaped America|location=New York|publisher=Harper Perennial|pages=134–9|isbn=978-0-06-057488-8}} White Christian concepts taught to black persons that they are to be disregarded or ignored.{{citation needed|date=March 2018}} The aspects of [[Trinity|God's person]], his power and authority, as well as "subtle indications of God's white maleness" are said{{by whom|date=March 2018}} not to relate to the black experience, to the extent of sometimes being [[antagonism (philosophy)|antagonistic]]. While trinitarian theology is a big concern, Jesus is still considered to be God. The focus is given to God's actions and his delivering of the oppressed because of his righteousness. [[Immanence]] is stressed over [[transcendence (religion)|transcendence]], and as a result God is seen to be "in flux" or "always changing".Charts of Christian Theology and Doctrine by H. Wayne House Likewise, Cone based much of his liberationist theology on God's deliverance of Israel from Egypt in the [[Book of Exodus]]. He compared the United States to Egypt, predicting that oppressed people will soon be led to a [[promised land]]. For Cone, the theme of Yahweh's concern was for "the lack of social, economic, and political justice for those who are poor and unwanted in society."{{cite book|last=Cone|first=James H. |title=A Black Theology of Liberation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mqfsPwxuLrEC|year=2010|publisher=Orbis Books|location=Maryknoll, NY|isbn=978-1-60833-036-2|page=2}} Cone also says that the same God is working for the oppressed Blacks of the 20th century, and that "God is helping oppressed Blacks and has identified with them, God Himself is spoken of as 'Black'."{{cite web|url=http://home.earthlink.net/~ronrhodes/BlackTheology.html|title= Black Theology, Black Power, and the Black Experience |first=Ron |last=Rhodes |date=Spring 1991|publisher=Christian Research Journal}} Cone saw Christ from the aspect of oppression and liberation. Cone uses the Gospel of Luke to illustrate this point: "the blind receive their sight, the lame walk, the lepers are cleansed, the deaf hear, the dead are raised up, and the poor have the good news preached to them" (Luke 7:22). "'In Christ,' Cone argues, 'God enters human affairs and takes sides with the oppressed. Their suffering becomes his; their despair, divine despair.'" Cone also argues that, "We cannot solve ethical questions of the twentieth century by looking at what Jesus did in the first. Our choices are not the same as his. Being Christians does not mean following 'in his steps.'"{{cite book|last=Cone|first=James H. |title=Black Theology and Black Power|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FOgAs4hcbn8C|year=2008|publisher=Orbis Books|location=Maryknoll, NY|isbn=978-1-60833-037-9|page=115}} Cone objected to the persistent portrayal of Jesus as White. "It's very important because you've got a lot of white images of Christ. In reality, Christ was not white, not European. That's important to the psychic and to the spiritual consciousness of Black people who live in a ghetto and in a white society in which their lord and savior looks just like people who victimize them. God is whatever color God needs to be in order to let people know they're not nobodies, they're somebodies." {{cite news|title=James H. Cone|last=Reynolds|first=Barbara|publisher=''USA Today''|date=November 8, 1989|page=11A}} === Stylistic differences in the Black religious community === Because of the differences in thought between the Black and White community, most Black religious leaders attempt to make their services more accessible to other African-Americans, who must identify with the faith in order to accept it. Another notable difference is Cone's suggestion as to what must occur if there is not reconciliation among the White community. He states, "Whether the American system is beyond redemption we will have to wait and see. But we can be certain that Black patience has run out, and unless White America responds positively to the theory and activity of Black Power, then a bloody, protracted civil war is inevitable."{{cite book|last=Cone|first=James H. |title=Black Theology and Black Power|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FOgAs4hcbn8C|year=2008|publisher=Orbis Books|location=Maryknoll, NY|isbn=978-1-60833-037-9|page=118}} Black theology is considered by some to be a form of racism{{by who|date=August 2018}}, as some followers associate liberation with retribution and anger[[weasel words]]. Some suggest that this is a response to the discomfort some White Americans feel with the ideas of Black empowerment and threat of being dealt with unapologetically as equals. It should also be noted that Christ forgave his oppressors and there is no focus on retribution for past wrong in the writings of Cone and other leaders. === Criticisms === Anthony Bradley of the ''[[Christian Post]]'' interprets that the language of "economic parity" and references to "mal-distribution" as nothing more than channeling the views of Karl Marx. He believes James Cone and [[Cornel West]] have worked to incorporate Marxist thought into the Black church, forming an ethical framework predicated on a system of oppressor class versus a victim much like Marxism.{{cite web|url= http://www.acton.org/commentary/443_marxist_roots_of_black_liberation_theology|title=The Marxist roots of Black Liberation Theology|first=Anthony B.|last=Bradley|date= April 2, 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080405004249/http://www.acton.org:80/commentary/443_marxist_roots_of_black_liberation_theology.php|archive-date=April 5, 2008|publisher=Acton Institute}} [[Trinity United Church of Christ, Chicago]] has been cited in the press and by Cone as the best example of a church formally founded on the vision of Black theology. The 2008 [[Jeremiah Wright controversy]], over alleged racism and anti-Americanism in Wright's sermons and statements, caused then-Senator [[Barack Obama]] to distance himself from his former pastor.{{cite web|url=http://www.iht.com/articles/2008/05/01/opinion/edderber.php|title=The 'Wright problem'|last1=Derber|first1=Charles|last2=Magrass|first2=Yale|date=May 1, 2008}} [[Stanley Kurtz]] of the [[National Review]] wrote about the perceived differences with 'conventional American Christianity'. He quoted Black theologian Obery M. Hendricks Jr.: "According to Hendricks, 'many good church-going folk have been deluded into behaving like modern-day Pharisees and Sadducees when they think they're really being good Christians.' Unwittingly, Hendricks says, these apparent Christians have actually become 'like the false prophets of Ba'al.'" Kurtz also quotes the Rev. Jeremiah Wright: "How do I tell my children about the African Jesus who is not the guy they see in the picture of the blond-haired, blue-eyed guy in their Bible or the figment of white supremacists {{sic}} imagination that they see in Mel Gibson's movies?"{{cite web|url=http://www.nationalreview.com/articles/224530/left-church/stanley-kurtz?|title=Left in Church|author=Kurtz, Stanley|date=May 20, 2008|publisher=''[[National Review]]''|page=4}} == Black theology in South Africa == Black theology was popularized in southern Africa in the early 1970s by [[Basil Moore (theologian)|Basil Moore]], a [[Methodist]] theologian in [[South Africa]]. It helped to give rise to, and developed in parallel with, the [[Black Consciousness Movement]]. Black theology was particularly influential in [[South Africa]] and [[Namibia]] for motivating resistance to [[apartheid]].{{Cite book|url=http://universitypublishingonline.org/ref/id/companions/CBO9781139025560A023|title=The Cambridge Companion to Black Theology|last=Motlhabi|first=Mokgethi|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=2012|isbn=9781139025560|editor-last=Hopkins|editor-first=Dwight N.|location=Cambridge|pages=221–233|chapter=The History of Black Theology in South Africa|doi=10.1017/ccol9780521879866.017|quote=|editor-last2=Antonio|editor-first2=Edward P.|via=}} This movement would also see be closely related to the South African [[Kairos Document]].{{Cite journal|last=Vellem|first=Vuyani S.|date=2010|title=Prophetic Theology in Black Theology, with special reference to the ''Kairos document''|url=http://www.hts.org.za/index.php/HTS/article/view/800/1179|journal=HTS Teologiese Studies / Theological Studies|language=en|volume=66|issue=1|doi=10.4102/hts.v66i1.800|issn=2072-8050}} Southern African black theologians include [[Barney Pityana]], [[Allan Boesak]], [[Itumeleng Mosala]] and [[Zephania Kameeta]]. In the African continent, black theology is often distinguished from [[African theology]]. == Black theology in Britain == In the [[United Kingdom]], [[Robert Beckford]] is a prominent black theology practitioner. He was the first in the UK to develop and teach a course on Black theology at an academic level.{{Cite book|url=http://universitypublishingonline.org/ref/id/companions/CBO9781139025560A023|title=The Cambridge Companion to Black Theology|last=Reddie|first=Anthony|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=2012|isbn=|editor-last=Hopkins|editor-first=Dwight N.|location=Cambridge|pages=234–244|chapter=The History of Black Theology in Britain|doi=10.1017/CCOL9780521879866.018|quote=|editor-last2=Antonio|editor-first2=Edward P.|via=}} Although it is not limited to the British context, an [[academic journal]] which has been a key outlet for the discourse around Black theology in Britain has been ''Black Theology'', edited by [[Anthony G. Reddie]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/action/journalInformation?journalCode=yblt20|title=Black Theology: An International Journal|last=|first=|date=|website=www.tandfonline.com|publisher=|access-date=27 September 2016}}{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5sDsCwAAQBAJ|title=Black Theology in Britain: A Reader|last=|first=|date=2016|publisher=Routledge|year=|isbn=9781134964550|editor-last=Jagessar|editor-first=Michael N.|location=New York|pages=1–20|language=en|editor-last2=Reddie|editor-first2=Anthony G.|via=}} == See also == {{Portal|Christianity|African American}} ;Significant figures * [[Albert Cleage]] * [[James Hal Cone]] * [[W. E. B. Du Bois]] * [[Dwight N. Hopkins]] * [[Martin Luther King Jr.|Martin Luther King, Jr.]] * [[Cornel West]] * [[Jeremiah Wright]] ;Related topics * [[African theology]] * [[Black Consciousness Movement|Black consciousness movement]] * [[Black Power movement|Black power movement]] * [[Kairos Document]] * [[Womanist theology]] * [[Liberation Theology]] == References == {{reflist|30em}} === Bibliography === {{refbegin|indent=yes}} : {{cite book|last=Cone|first=James H. |title=Black Theology and Black Power|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FOgAs4hcbn8C|year=2008|publisher=Orbis Books|location=Maryknoll, NY|isbn=978-1-60833-037-9|ref=harv}} : {{cite book|last=Cone|first=James H. |title=A Black Theology of Liberation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mqfsPwxuLrEC|year=2010|publisher=Orbis Books|location=Maryknoll, NY|isbn=978-1-60833-036-2|ref=harv}} {{refend}} == Further reading == * [[Bibliography of Black theology]] == External links == * ''[http://www.tandfonline.com/action/journalInformation?journalCode=yblt20 Black Theology: An International Journal]'' {{DEFAULTSORT:Black Theology}} [[Category:Religion and politics]] [[Category:Christianity in the United States]] [[Category:African-American Christianity]] [[Category:Christianity in South Africa]] [[Category:Christian theological movements]] [[Category:Africana philosophy]] [[Category:African-American culture]] [[Category:World Christianity]]

[[Robert Reffkin]] | industry = [[Real Estate]] | url = {{URL|https://compass.com/}} | company_type = [[Privately held company|Private]] | location_city = [[New York City|New York]], [[New York (state)|New York]] | location_country = [[United States|US]]{{cite web |url=https://techcrunch.com/2015/09/15/compass-50m-real-estate/ |title=Compass Raises $50M at An $800M Valuation Led By IVP To Supersize Its Real Estate Platform |first=Ingrid |last=Lunden |publisher=}} | foundation = {{Start date and age|2012|}} | incorporated = | key_people = {{nowrap|Ori Allon (Co-Founder and Executive Chairman)}}
{{nowrap|Robert Reffkin (Co-Founder and CEO)}}
| launch_date = {{start date and age|2013|5}} | native_clients = [[Website]], [[iPad]], [[iPhone]], [[Android (operating system)|Android]] | area_served = [[Aspen, CO|Aspen]], [[Atlanta, GA|Atlanta]], [[Boston]], [[Chicago]], [[Dallas]], [[Greenwich, CT|Greenwich]], [[Los Angeles]], [[Orange County, California|Orange County]], [[Miami]], [[New York City]], [[Philadelphia]], [[San Diego]], [[San Francisco Bay]], [[Santa Barbara, California|Santa Barbara]], [[Montecito, CA|Montecito]], [[Seattle]], [[The Hamptons]], [[Washington, D.C.]], and [[Westchester, NY|Westchester]]{{cite web |author=Compass |url=https://www.compass.com/about/offices |title=Our regional offices, from coast to coast. |publisher=Compass |date= |accessdate=2018-08-06}} }} '''Compass''' is an American [[real estate technology]] company. Founded in 2012, the company is headquartered in New York City.{{cite web |url=https://techcrunch.com/2015/09/15/compass-50m-real-estate/ |title=Compass Raises $50M at An $800M Valuation Led By IVP To Supersize Its Real Estate Platform |first=Ingrid |last=Lunden |publisher=}} The company provides software to real estate agents to eliminate busy work and help them become more efficient. Compass is said to be the first company to have built a proprietary mobile app for real estate agents.{{cite web |url=https://www.entrepreneur.com/article/281616# |title=25 Inspiring Entrepreneurs Under 40 Who Are Creating the Next Big Thing |first=Andre |last=Bourque |date=28 September 2016 |publisher=}} Compass has a current valuation upwards of US$4.4 billion.{{cite web |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/real-estate-is-latest-target-for-would-be-disrupters-1487327401 |title=Real Estate Is Latest Target for Would-Be Disrupters |first1=Eliot |last1=Brown |first2=Laura |last2=Kusisto |date=17 February 2017 |publisher= |via=www.wsj.com}} The company operates in 17 U.S. markets including New York, Boston, Washington D.C., South Florida, San Francisco, Chicago, Los Angeles, Aspen, The Hamptons, Santa Barbara{{cite web |url=https://techcrunch.com/2017/01/18/maelle-gavet-is-the-new-coo-at-real-estate-startup-compass/ |title=Maelle Gavet is the new COO at real estate startup Compass |first=Ingrid |last=Lunden |publisher=}} and Newport Beach.{{cite web |url=http://www.ocregister.com/2017/02/05/luxury-real-estate-startup-compass-expands-to-newport-beach-scores-top-agent-rob-giem/ |title=Luxury real estate startup Compass expands to Newport Beach, scores top agent Rob Giem |date=5 February 2017 |publisher=}} == Founding and Funding == The company was founded by entrepreneurs Ori Allon and [[Robert Reffkin]]. Allon had previously sold companies to [[Google]] and [[Twitter]].{{cite web |url=https://www.theverge.com/2012/11/27/3692738/ori-allon-urban-compass-twitter-google-goldman-sachs |title=After cashing out to Google and Twitter, Ori Allon is going all in with Urban Compass |publisher=}} Reffkin previously served as the chief of staff to the president of [[Goldman Sachs]]{{cite web |url=https://www.fastcompany.com/3047603/why-this-real-estate-app-is-making-new-york-brokers-nervous |title=Why This Real Estate App Is Making New York Brokers Nervous |date=18 June 2015 |publisher=}} and worked in [[The White House]].{{cite web |url=http://fortune.com/2014/10/13/modernizing-the-new-york-apartment-hunt/ |title=Modernizing the New York apartment hunt |publisher=}} Compass has raised a total of $1.2 billion{{Cite news |url=https://techcrunch.com/2018/09/27/safe-as-houses-compass-400m-real-estate-unicorn/ |title=Compass nabs $400M, valuing the real estate technology startup at $4.4B |work=TechCrunch |access-date=2018-11-05 |language=en-US}} from investors such as [[Founders Fund|Founder's Fund]], [[Wellington Management Group|Wellington Management]] and [[Institutional Venture Partners]], [[Fidelity Investments]]{{Cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-11-08/tech-startup-or-real-estate-broker-fidelity-values-compass-at-2-billion |title=Tech Startup or Real-Estate Broker? Fidelity Values Compass at $2 Billion |date=2017-11-08 |work=Bloomberg.com |access-date=2017-12-25}} and [[SoftBank Group|Softbank]] Vision Fund.{{Cite news |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2017/12/07/softbank-invests-450-million-in-real-estate-tech-company-compass.html |title=Softbank invests $450 million in real estate tech company Compass |last=Jr. |first=Berkeley Lovelace |date=2017-12-07 |work=CNBC |access-date=2017-12-25}} Compass was named Mid-Sized Business of the Year by the Manhattan Chamber of Commerce in 2015. == History == Compass was originally founded as Urban Compass in late 2012.{{cite web |url=https://techcrunch.com/2012/12/16/urban-compass/ |title=With $8M in Seed Funding From Founders Fund, Goldman Sachs; Urban Compass Wants To Build A Hyper-Local, Human-Powered Database |first=Ingrid |last=Lunden |publisher=}} The company raised $8mm of seed fundraising from Founder's Fund, Thrive Capital, Goldman Sachs as well as several individual investors including [[American Express]] CEO [[Kenneth Chenault]], and [[ZocDoc]] CEO [[Cyrus Massoumi]]. The initial business model employed full-time, salaried brokers, who users of the platform could schedule appointments online with after searching for listings on the company's desktop or mobile app.{{cite web |url=https://www.theverge.com/2013/5/7/4304374/urban-compass |title=Urban Compass: can a startup finally fix the nightmare of renting an apartment in NYC? |publisher=}} The company publicly debuted at an event in May 2013, where then-New York City Mayor [[Michael Bloomberg]] helped celebrate the launch.{{cite web |url=https://techcrunch.com/2013/05/07/urban-compass-debuts-a-hyperlocal-social-network-and-a-rental-portal-to-serve-as-its-magnet/ |title=Urban Compass Comes Out Of Stealth with a Hyperlocal Social Network, And A Disruptive Rental Portal That Will Serve As A Magnet |first=Ingrid |last=Lunden |publisher=}}{{cite web |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/life-style/real-estate/nyc-tech-start-up-urban-compass-launches-real-estate-focused-site-article-1.1337613 |title=NYC tech start-up Urban Compass launches real estate focused site |publisher=}} The company initially focused only on rentals. In September 2013, the company raised a Series A financing round of $20M, at a reported valuation of $150M.{{cite web |url=https://techcrunch.com/2013/09/25/urban-compass-series-a/ |title=Hyperlocal Power: Urban Compass Raises $20M at A$150M Valuation; Adds Advance Publications And Marc Benioff As Investors |first=Ingrid |last=Lunden |publisher=}} Investors including [[Advance Publications]], the CEO of [[Salesforce.com]], [[Marc Benioff]], and .406 Ventures all invested in Compass at this stage.{{cite web |url=https://www.pehub.com/2013/09/new-york-city-startup-urban-compass-raises-20-mln-series-a-funds/ |title=- New York City startup Urban Compass raises $20 mln in Series A funds |website=www.pehub.com}} At the beginning of 2014, Compass announced they would enter the real estate sales business and a change in their overall business model, contracting independent real estate agents and taking a cut of the commission.{{cite web |url=https://www.inman.com/2014/01/15/the-big-pivot-why-urban-compass-has-gone-traditional/ |title=The big pivot: why Urban Compass has gone traditional |publisher=}} In July 2014, Compass raised a Series B financing round of $40M, this time at a valuation of $360M according to Bloomberg{{cite web |url=https://techcrunch.com/2014/07/21/urban-compass-raises-40m-series-b/ |title=Urban Compass Raises $40M To Expand Its Apartment Marketplace Beyond NYC |first=Colleen |last=Taylor |publisher=}} . Shortly following, Compass signed a lease on 25,000 square feet at 90 5th Avenue.{{cite web |url=https://commercialobserver.com/2014/07/urban-compass-signs-lease-at-rfrs-90-fifth-avenue/ |title=Urban Compass Signs Lease at RFR's 90 Fifth Avenue |date=22 July 2014 |publisher=}} The firm also hired Leonard Steinberg, a top-ranked real estate broker, from [[Douglas Elliman]] to serve as its president.{{cite web |url=https://therealdeal.com/2014/06/02/leonard-steinberg-exiting-douglas-elliman-for-urban-compass/ |title=Leonard Steinberg exits Douglas Elliman for Urban Compass |date=2 June 2014 |publisher=}}{{cite web |url=http://rew-online.com/2014/06/20/whos-news-17/ |title=WHO'S NEWS – Real Estate Weekly |date=20 June 2014 |publisher=}} Leonard Steinberg was named the agent with the highest sales volume in 2016 by Real Trends.{{cite web |url=https://www.inman.com/2016/06/24/real-trendswsj-thousand-list-2016-unveiled/ |title=The Real Trends/WSJ Thousand list for 2016 has been unveiled |publisher=}} The company reported having 125 agents and 70 staff at this time.https://www.inman.com/2014/11/15/urban-compass-launches-nationwide-expansion-push-with-washington-d-c-acquisition/ In September 2015, Compass raised a Series C financing round of $50M at a reported valuation of $800M. The investment was led by [[Institutional Venture Partners]].{{cite web |url=https://therealdeal.com/2015/09/15/compass-raises-50m-in-series-c-now-valued-at-800m/ |title=Compass raises $50M in Series C; now valued at $800M |date=15 September 2015 |publisher=}} The company also opened offices in Brooklyn, South Florida, Boston and The Hamptons.{{cite web |url=https://therealdeal.com/miami/2015/08/21/compass-opens-first-sofla-office-on-lincoln-road/ |title=Compass opens first SoFla office on Lincoln Road |date=21 August 2015 |publisher=}}{{cite web |url=https://therealdeal.com/2014/09/10/urban-compass-picks-up-top-team-from-citi-habitats/ |title=Urban Compass picks up top team from Citi Habitats |date=10 September 2014 |publisher=}}{{cite web |url=https://www.inman.com/2015/09/30/compass-riding-50m-funding-round-into-boston/ |title=Compass riding $50M funding round into Boston |publisher=}}{{cite web |url=https://therealdeal.com/2015/09/04/compass-turns-to-the-hamptons-where-rivals-roam/ |title=Compass turns to the Hamptons, where rivals roam |date=4 September 2015 |publisher=}} In August 2016, Compass raised a Series D financing round of $75M, led by [[Wellington Management]], which brought its valuation to north of $1B.{{cite web |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/compass-raises-funding-worth-over-1-billion-2016-8 |title=This startup that wants to blow up the real-estate market is now worth more than $1 billion |publisher=}}{{cite web |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-08-31/compass-said-to-win-1-billion-valuation-as-new-unicorns-become-rarer |title=Compass Earns $1 Billion Valuation As New Unicorns Become Rarer |date=31 August 2016 |publisher= |via=www.bloomberg.com}} The company also launched a new mobile app that offers real-time data on the real estate market.{{cite web |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/compass-real-estate-startup-launches-new-app-2016-7 |title=This $800 million startup just launched an app to make buying a home easier |publisher=}} Earlier in the year, the company expanded into Aspen with the acquisition of Shane Aspen Real Estate{{cite web |url=http://www.aspentimes.com/news/tech-company-compass-acquires-shane-aspen-real-estate/ |title=Tech company Compass acquires Shane Aspen Real Estate |publisher=}} as well as Los Angeles.{{cite web |url=https://therealdeal.com/la/2016/07/18/compass-to-launch-la-new-dev-division-on-heels-of-hana-cha-hire/ |title=Compass to launch LA new dev division on heels of Hana Cha hire |date=18 July 2016 |publisher=}} Reports also cited Compass’ expansion into Santa Barbara and San Francisco{{cite web |url=https://therealdeal.com/2016/09/02/compass-now-claims-its-agents-account-for-8b-in-sales-but-whats-that-number-made-of/ |title=Compass now claims its agents account for $8B in sales -- but what's that number made of? |date=2 September 2016 |publisher=}} as well as several other smaller sub-markets of their other major metro areas.http://www.businessinsider.com/compass-raises-funding-worth-over-1-billion-2016-8 Throughout 2017, Compass hired several new executives to its leadership team, including Madan Nagaldinne, a former [[Facebook]] and [[Amazon.com|Amazon]] executive as Chief People Officer{{cite web |url=http://rew-online.com/2017/08/23/compass-hires-facebook-alumnus-to-steer-recruitment-strategy/ |title=Compass hires Facebook alumnus to steer recruitment strategy – Real Estate Weekly |date=23 August 2017 |publisher=}}, and Craig Anderson, a former Flywheel executive as chief financial officer.{{cite web |url=http://www.crainsnewyork.com/article/20170830/REAL_ESTATE/170839997/real-estate-tech-firm-compass-replaces-chief-financial-officer |title=Compass replaces chief financial officer |first=Peter |last=D'Amato |publisher=}} In November 2017, Compass announced $100M Series E Investment by [[Fidelity Investments]], followed by Dec 7th, 2017 announcement of $450M investment by [[SoftBank Group|Softbank]] Vision Fund, later bringing the company valuation to $2.2B. Compass also expanded into Chicago in late November, signing the city's number one real estate team.{{Cite news |url=http://www.chicagobusiness.com/realestate/20171128/CRED0701/171129920/citys-top-selling-residential-broker-team-jumps-to-new-in-town-firm |title=City's top-selling residential broker team jumps to new-in-town firm |work=Crain's Chicago Business |access-date=2017-12-25}} Additionally, Compass announced aggressive expansion plans to 9 more cities.{{Cite news |url=https://www.inman.com/2017/11/07/compass-reveals-plans-for-massive-expansion-futuristic-signage/ |title=Compass reveals plans for massive expansion |work=Inman |access-date=2017-12-25 |language=en-US}} Less than a year later in September 2018, Compass announced a $400M Series F at a valuation to $4.4B.{{Cite news |url=https://techcrunch.com/2018/09/27/safe-as-houses-compass-400m-real-estate-unicorn/ |title=Compass nabs $400M, valuing the real estate technology startup at $4.4B |work=TechCrunch |access-date=2018-09-28 |language=en-US}} This series was led by [[SoftBank Group|Softbank]] Vision Fund and [[Qatar Investment Authority]], other investors included, [[Wellington Management Company|Wellington Management]], [[Institutional Venture Partners]] and [[Fidelity Investments]]. Compass also announced plans to use these funds to enter international markets and double down on creating world leading technology.{{Cite news |url=https://therealdeal.com/2018/09/27/compass-raises-400m-from-softbank-qatar-investment-authority/ |title=Compass raises $400M from SoftBank, QIA; brokerage now valued at $4.4B |date=2018-09-27 |work=The Real Deal New York |access-date=2018-09-28 |language=en-US}} Compass plans to launch Nashville, Houston, and Denver before the end of 2018. == References == {{reflist}} [[Category:Real estate]] [[Category:Real estate services companies of the United States]] [[Category:Companies based in New York City]] [[Category:Software companies based in New York City]] [[Category:American companies established in 2012]]

Christopher King |programmer = Henrik Fåhraeus
Johan Lerström
Fredrik Zetterman |artist = Fredrik Toll |composer = Andreas Waldetoft }} '''''Crusader Kings II''''' is a [[Grand strategy wargame|grand strategy game]] set in the [[Middle Ages]], [[video game developer|developed]] by [[Paradox Development Studio]] and [[video game publisher|published]] by [[Paradox Interactive]] as a sequel to ''[[Crusader Kings (video game)|Crusader Kings]]''. It was released for [[Microsoft Windows]] on February 14, 2012. An [[OS X]] version, Paradox Interactive's first in-house development for the [[operating system]], was released on May 24, 2012. A [[Linux]] version was also released on January 14, 2013. It has sold over 1 million copies, which made it Paradox's most successful release before [[Europa Universalis IV]].''{{cite web|url=https://www.pcgamesn.com/crusader-kings-ii/how-crusader-kings-2-caught-paradox-by-surprise|title=How Crusader Kings 2 caught Paradox by surprise|last=Zacny|first=Rob|date=September 20, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140922004213/http://www.pcgamesn.com/crusader-kings-ii/how-crusader-kings-2-caught-paradox-by-surprise|archivedate=September 22, 2014}} ==Gameplay== The game is a [[dynasty]] [[simulator]] where the player controls a [[Middle Ages|Medieval]] dynasty from 1066 to 1453, though the [[downloadable content|DLC]] ''The Old Gods'' and ''Charlemagne'' allow for earlier start dates of 867 and 769, respectively. Through the strategic use of war, marriages and assassinations among many other things, the player works to achieve success for their dynasty. The game contains numerous historical figures such as [[William the Conqueror]], [[Charlemagne]], [[Genghis Khan]], [[Harold Godwinson]], [[Robert Guiscard]], [[Robert the Bruce]], [[Harald Hardrada]], [[El Cid]], [[Constantine X Doukas]], [[Harun al-Rashid]], [[Alexios I Komnenos]], [[Richard the Lionheart]], [[Ivar the Boneless]], [[Alfred the Great]], [[Baldwin I of Jerusalem]], and [[Saladin]], but allows for the player to choose less significant figures such as minor dukes and counts, and creation of entirely new characters with the use of the "Ruler Designer" DLC. Success is defined solely by the player. The only in-game objective is to obtain as many prestige and piety points as possible in order to surpass the various historically relevant European dynasties in a fictional prestige ranking (the three most prestigious ones being the [[House of Capet|Capetian]], the [[Rurikid|Rurikovich]] and the [[House of Habsburg|Habsburg]] dynasties). The game ends when the player's current character dies without an heir of the same dynasty to succeed him/her, when all landed titles of the count rank or above are stripped from all members of the player's dynasty (including themselves), or when the game reaches its end in 1453. The game employs a genetics and education system where children will inherit many traits, culture, religion and skills from their parents and guardian. This adds an additional layer of strategy to marriages, such that a player will attempt not only to form beneficial alliances, but also to select marriage partners with strong heritable traits to maximise the quality of offspring and thus strengthen the dynasty. This requires balancing sometimes conflicting interests. For example, while one possible marriage might allow some [[Marriage alliances|desirable alliance]] to be formed with another ruler, it may also require marrying a spouse with some undesirable traits. Such a trade-off can occur in the reverse as well: one possible spouse could possess highly desirable traits but yield no new alliances for the player's dynasty.{{cite web |url=http://www.bit-tech.net/gaming/pc/2011/02/09/crusader-kings-2-preview/2 |title=Crusader Kings 2 PC Preview |author=Joe Martin |publisher=bit-tech |date=February 9, 2012 |accessdate=September 6, 2012}} While the player can choose any noble with at least a county in their possession to play as, there are some government types that are unplayable without [[Mod (video gaming)|modding]] the game. These include theocracies (such as [[Pope|The Papacy]]), holy orders, mercenaries, and republics. The [[Maritime republics|merchant republic]] government type, however, is playable with ''The Republic'' expansion. In addition, all non-[[Christianity|Christian]] characters are unplayable without the purchase of the DLC that unlocks them, including [[Muslim]]s, [[Jews]], [[Hinduism|Hindus]], [[Buddhism|Buddhists]], [[Taoism|Taoists]], [[Zoroastrianism|Zoroastrians]], [[Jainism|Jains]], [[Zunism|Zunists]] and various [[Paganism|Pagans]]. ===Expansion packs=== {| class="wikitable" style="width: 100%;" ! style="width: 15%;height:50px;" |Name ! style="width: 15%;" |Release date !Accompanying Patch !Description |- |'''''[[Crusader Kings II: Sword of Islam|Sword of Islam]]''''' |26 June 2012 |1.06 |This expansion pack allows the player to play as Muslim rulers. It also adds story events involving [[Sunni]] and [[Shia]] Muslims.{{cite news|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/crusader-kings-2-sword-of-islam-expansion-announced-will-let-you-side-with-saladin/|title=Crusader Kings 2 Sword of Islam expansion announced, will let you side with Saladin|last1=Hatfield|first1=Tom|date=31 May 2012|work=[[PC Gamer]]|accessdate=25 November 2017}} |- |'''''Legacy of Rome''''' |16 October 2012 |1.07 |''Legacy of Rome'' is focused around the [[Byzantine Empire]], adding new events and game mechanics. It also adds the "Retinue" mechanic allowing the player to maintain a standing army.{{cite news|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/crusader-kings-2-legacy-of-rome-expansion/|title=Crusader Kings 2: Legacy of Rome expansion lets you flex your Byzantium Maximus|last1=Petitte|first1=Omri|date=30 August 2012|work=PC Gamer|accessdate=25 November 2017}} |- |'''''Sunset Invasion''''' |15 November 2012 |1.08 |The main feature of ''Sunset Invasion'' is the fictional invasion of more technologically advanced [[Aztecs]], from the late 13th century onwards to the end of the game alongside a new religion and culture unique to them.{{cite news|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/crusader-kings-ii-dlc-sacrifices-history-adds-aztec-invasion-of-europe/|title=Crusader Kings II DLC sacrifices history, adds Aztec invasion of Europe|last1=Hafer|first1=T.J.|date=31 October 2012|work=PC Gamer|accessdate=25 November 2017}} |- |'''''The Republic''''' |15 Jan 2013 |1.09 |Makes naval-based merchant republics playable with their own unique play-style centering around wealth and elections. It also a few new casus bellis and events concerning Republican politics and familial feuds. |- |'''''The Old Gods''''' |28 May 2013 |1.10 |Adds a new [[867 AD]] start date and makes pagans playable with their own unique mechanics. Also unlocks new revolt mechanics and adventurer claimants. |- |'''''[[Crusader Kings II: Sons of Abraham|Sons of Abraham]]''''' |18 November 2013 |2.0 |Gives further depth to the three [[Abrahamic Faiths|Abrahamic faiths]]; Christianity in particular, but has also added some content for Muslims, as well as the Jewish faith. Also adds Holy Orders for all faiths alongside new Events. |- |'''''Rajas of India''''' |25 March 2014 |2.1 |Makes Hindu, Buddhist and Jain rulers playable. Expands the map as far east as Bengal. With Patch 2.8, Taoist rulers will now also be unlocked by this DLC. |- |'''''Charlemagne''''' |14 October 2014 |2.2 |Unlocks several improvements to narrative aspects of the game, custom kingdoms and empires, vice royalty and the [[769]] start date. |- |'''''Way of Life''''' |16 December 2014 |2.3 |Improves role-playing and immersion, by letting player influence more directly the type of events that may happen, rather than relying solely on personality traits or randomness. |- |'''''Horse Lords''''' |14 July 2015 |2.4 |Unlocks playing as a nomadic government. |- |'''''Conclave''''' |2 February 2016 |2.5 |Improves interaction with your vassals, gives power to the council and overhauls the education for children system. |- |'''''The Reaper's Due''''' |25 August 2016 |2.6 |Improves the Plague, epidemics, minor diseases, prosperity and interactions with your court. |- |'''''Monks and Mystics''''' |7 March 2017 |2.7 |Adds societies, artfacts and relics, new councilor jobs and the ability to give commands to allied armies. |- |'''''Jade Dragon''''' |16 November 2017 |2.8 |Adds interactions with China, new Chinese artifacts, new Casus Bellis, and Rally Points along with making the Tibetan plateau playable. |- |'''''Holy Fury''''' |13 November 2018{{cite news |last1=Horti |first1=Samuel |title=Crusader Kings 2's Holy Fury DLC release date announced |url=https://www.pcgamer.com/crusader-kings-2s-holy-fury-dlc-release-date-announced/ |accessdate=14 October 2018 |work=pcgamer |date=13 October 2018 |language=en}} |3.0 |Allows the player to "design" Pagan religions upon reformation, introduces new crusade mechanics and events, mechanics for coronations, sainthood and bloodlines and also includes shattered and random maps.{{cite web|url=https://www.pcgamer.com/crusader-kings-2-unveils-holy-fury-dlc/|title=Crusader Kings 2 unveils Holy Fury DLC|last1=Donelly|first1=Joe|website=PC Gamer|language=en|accessdate=19 May 2018}} |- |} ==Release and reception== {{Video game reviews | MC = 82/100{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/crusader-kings-ii |title=Crusader Kings II for PC Reviews |publisher=Metacritic |date=2012-02-14 |accessdate=2013-04-21}} | GSpot = 8/10{{cite web |url=http://www.gamespot.com/reviews/crusader-kings-ii-review/1900-6350562/ |title=Crusader Kings II Review |publisher=[[GameSpot]] |author=Shaun McInnis |date=February 16, 2012 |accessdate=September 6, 2012 }} | IGN = 8/10{{cite web |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2012/03/05/crusader-kings-ii-review |title=Crusader Kings II Review |publisher=IGN |author=Eric Neigher |date=March 5, 2012 |accessdate=September 6, 2012 }} | PCPP = 7/10{{Citation|last=Zacny|first=Rob|date=1 May 2012|title=Crusader Kings II|magazine=[[PC PowerPlay]]|issue=203|publisher=[[nextmedia]]|place=Australia|page=52}} }} A [[Game demo|demo]] was released on February 4, 2012, which featured four playable characters over a 20-year span.{{cite web|url=http://www.fileplanet.com/224596/download/Crusader-Kings-II-Demo |title=Crusader Kings II Demo |publisher=Fileplanet.com |date= |accessdate=2013-04-21}} A marketing campaign for the game featured light comedy videos on the concept of the [[Seven Deadly Sins]].{{cite web|url=http://www.rtsguru.com/game/286/article/1796/Crusader-Kings-II-Greed-Enters-the-Fray-in-The-Latest-Deadly-Sins-Comic-Trailer.html|title=Crusader Kings II: Greed Enters the Fray in The Latest Deadly Sins Comic Trailer|date=10 January 2012|accessdate=22 June 2013|last=Gonzalez|first=Christina|publisher=RTSguru.com}} The game was met with generally positive reviews and has attained a metascore of 82 at [[Metacritic]].{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/crusader-kings-ii |title=Crusader Kings II for PC Reviews |publisher=Metacritic |date= |accessdate=2015-09-30}} [[GameSpot]] reviewer Shaun McInnis stated "Through a complex system of diplomacy and backstabbing, ''Crusader Kings II'' makes every power struggle an engrossing one" and he lauded the gameplay while noting the "lackluster tutorials". [[IGN]] summed up their review by saying "An intense learning curve, but a unique strategy experience". IGN rated the gameplay and "lasting appeal" a 9/10. A reviewer for [[Rock, Paper, Shotgun|''Rock, Paper, Shotgu''n]] stated that ''Crusader Kings II'' was "probably the most human strategy game" he ever played.{{cite web |url=http://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2012/02/23/wot-i-think-crusader-kings-ii/ |title=Wot I Think: Crusader Kings II |publisher=Rock, Paper, Shotgun |author=Adam Smith |date=2012-02-23 |accessdate=2013-02-02| quote=''When the consequences are so human they mean all the much more and this is probably the most human strategy game I’ve ever played. If it doesn’t wind up being among my very favourite games of the year, spectacular things will occur in the next ten months.''}} Rob Zacny of ''[[PC PowerPlay]]'', who gave the game a 7/10 score, called it a "brilliant treatment of [[feudalism]] in terms of strategy and story" but also stated it "requires major investment to overcome [[information overload]]". ''[[Kotaku]]'' named the game as one of their game of the year nominees.{{cite web|url=http://kotaku.com/5972744/why-crusader-kings-ii-should-be-game-of-the-year|title=Why Crusader Kings II Should Be Game Of The Year|last=Plunkett|first=Luke|date=4 January 2013|work=[[Kotaku]]|publisher=[[Gawker Media]]|accessdate=10 August 2013}} By September 2014, ''Crusader Kings II'' had sold more than 1 million copies, with the expansion pack and DLC sales totaling over 7 million units. According to [[Paradox Interactive]], the game was played by an average of 12,500 players every day, with an average playtime of 99 hours per player.{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141110221627/http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/225929/Aiming_for_the_niche_pays_off_for_millionselling_strategy_game.php |url=http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/225929/Aiming_for_the_niche_pays_off_for_millionselling_strategy_game.php |title=Aiming for the 'niche' pays off for million-selling strategy game | author=Graft, Kris | date=September 18, 2014 |work=[[Gamasutra]] |archivedate=November 10, 2014 |deadurl=yes |df= }} ==Modding== When a Crusader Kings II (CK2) game is launched, Paradox servers collect information about the game setup such as game version, single player or multiplayer, and what mods are in use.{{Cite web|url=https://forum.paradoxplaza.com/forum/index.php?threads/ck2-dev-diary-49-mods-and-mod-telemetry.1016606/|title=CK2 Dev Diary #49: Mods and mod telemetry|last=|first= |date=2018-01-18|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} Data collected on 23 April 2017 showed that at least 42% of users on that day had activated at least one mod. Data also reveals that multiplayer "[[Cheating in video games|cheat mods]]" are popular too, as are graphics or [[Graphical user interface|GUI]] mods. A number of realism mods have been produced by fans such as ''Historical Immersion Project'' and ''CK2+.''{{Cite web|url=https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2017/03/23/best-crusader-kings-2-mods/|title=Best Crusader Kings 2 mods|last=Donnelly|first=Joe|date=2017-03-23|website=Rock, Paper, Shotgun|language=en-US|access-date=2018-01-19}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.twcenter.net/forums/showthread.php?644906-CK2-List-of-Mods|title=[CK2] List of Mods|website=www.twcenter.net|language=en|access-date=2018-01-20}} A number of [[Total conversion|total conversion mods]] are available: * ''A Game of Thrones'', based on [[George R. R. Martin]]'s ''[[A Song of Ice and Fire]]'' fantasy novels, released in May 2012,{{cite news|url=http://kotaku.com/5913709/there-is-an-awesome-game-of-thrones-video-game-you-can-play-it-right-now|title=There is an Awesome Game of Thrones Video Game. You Can Play it Right Now.|last=Plunkett|first=Luke|date=28 May 2012|newspaper=[[Kotaku]]|accessdate=May 31, 2012}}{{cite web|url=http://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2012/05/28/a-mod-of-a-game-of-thrones-crusader-kings-ii/|title=A Mod Of A Game Of Thrones: Crusader Kings II|author=Adam Smith|date=May 28, 2012|accessdate=2012-10-21|newspaper=[[Rock, Paper, Shotgun]]}}{{cite web|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/2013/04/08/crusader-kings-2s-game-of-thrones-mod-update-lets-you-feast-on-new-scenarios/|title=Crusader Kings 2's Game of Thrones mod update lets you feast on new scenarios | Mods, News|date=|publisher=PC Gamer|accessdate=2013-04-21}} which "has long been the most popular CK2 mod." * ''Elder Kings'', based on [[Bethesda Softworks]]'s ''[[The Elder Scrolls]]'' video game series, released on April 1, 2013. * ''Middle Earth Project,'' based on the works of [[J. R. R. Tolkien]], released 2014.{{Cite web|url=https://ck2.paradoxwikis.com/Middle_Earth_Project|title=Paradox Wiki|last=|first=|date=18 January 2018|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} * ''Witcher Kings'', based on [[Andrzej Sapkowski]]'s [[The Witcher]] series of novels, as well as [[CD Projekt|CD Projekt Red]]'s video game series. * ''After the End'', which is set in the 27th century in a post-apocalyptic North America. * ''The Winter King'', based on ''[[The Warlord Chronicles]]'' trilogy by [[Bernard Cornwell]]. * ''When the World Stopped Making Sense'',Which is set in the [[Dark Ages (historiography)|Dark Ages]] and adds Pre-[[East-West Schism|Schism]] Christian Denominations such as [[Nicene Christianity]],[[Arianism]] and [[Insular Christianity]] along with other religions such as [[Celtic Polytheism]] and [[Kemetism|Ancient Egyptian religion]]. Paradox actively encourages such modding, and the company is "constantly considering how we can ensure new additions to the game are moddable, and we often go back and tweak existing functionality to open it further to modding." ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{official website|http://www.crusaderkings.com}} *[http://www.ckiiwiki.com/Crusader_Kings_II_Wiki Official wiki for Crusader Kings II] {{Paradox development studio games}} {{Portal bar|Video games}} [[Category:2012 video games]] [[Category:Government simulation video games]] [[Category:Grand strategy video games]] [[Category:Linux games]] [[Category:MacOS games]] [[Category:Windows games]] [[Category:Video games set in the Middle Ages]] [[Category:Islam in fiction]] [[Category:Paradox Interactive games]] [[Category:Real-time strategy video games]] [[Category:Video game sequels]] [[Category:Video games with expansion packs]] [[Category:Video games with historical settings]] [[Category:Proprietary software that uses SDL]] [[Category:Steam Workshop games]] [[Category:Video games set in the Byzantine Empire]] [[Category:Video games set in the Crusades]] [[Category:Video games developed in Sweden]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Saladin]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Charlemagne]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of El Cid]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Richard I of England]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Alfred the Great]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Genghis Khan]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Ivar the Boneless]]
