{{Quote box |width = 25em |quote="Positive liberty... is a valid universal goal. I do not know why I should have been held to doubt this, or, for that matter, the further proposition, that democratic self-government is a fundamental human need, something valuable in itself, whether or not it clashes with the claims of negative liberty or of any other goal... What I am mainly concerned to establish is that, whatever may be the common ground between them, and whatever is liable to graver distortion, negative and positive liberty are not the same thing." |source = Isaiah Berlin, ''Five Essays on Liberty: An Introduction''Isaiah Berlin, (Oxford 2004) ''Liberty'', p 1–54 }} "'''Two Concepts of Liberty'''" was the inaugural [[lecture]] delivered by the liberal philosopher [[Isaiah Berlin]] before the [[University of Oxford]] on 31 October 1958. It was subsequently published as a 57-page pamphlet by Oxford at the [[Clarendon Press]]. It also appears in the collection of Berlin's papers entitled ''Four Essays on Liberty'' (1969) and was more recently reissued in a collection entitled simply ''Liberty'' (2002).Four Essays on Liberty, Oxford University Press, 1969. Superseded by Liberty. The essay, with its analytical approach to the definition of political concepts, re-introduced the study of political philosophy to the methods of [[analytic philosophy]].{{citation needed|date=August 2012}} It is also one of Berlin's first expressions of his ethical ontology of [[value-pluralism]]. Berlin defined negative liberty (as the term "liberty" was used by [[Thomas Hobbes]] Isaiah Berlin, (Oxford 2004) ''Liberty'', page 170) as the absence of coercion or interference with agents' possible private actions, by an exterior social-body. He also defined it as a comparatively recent political ideal, which re-emerged in the late 17th century, after its slow and inarticulate birth in the Ancient doctrines of [[Antiphon (person)|Antiphon the Sophist]], the [[Cyrenaics|Cyrenaic discipleship]], and of [[Otanes]] after the death of [[Bardiya|pseudo-Smerdis]].Isaiah Berlin, (Oxford 2004) ''Liberty'', page 33 In an introduction to the essay, Berlin writes:
"As for Otanes, he wished neither to rule nor to be ruled—the exact opposite of Aristotle's notion of true civic liberty. ... [This ideal] remains isolated and, until Epicurus, undeveloped ... the notion had not explicitly emerged".Isaiah Berlin, (Oxford 2004) ''Liberty'', ''Five Essays on Liberty: An Introduction'', page 33-4
== Summary == === Positive liberty === :"is involved in the answer to the question 'What, or who, is the source of control or interference that can determine someone to do, or be, this rather than that?' The two questions are clearly different, even though the answers to them may overlap."Berlin, I: "Two Concepts of Liberty",1958 [[Positive liberty]] may be understood as self-mastery, and includes one's having a role in choosing who governs the society of which one is a part.{{citation needed|date=August 2012}} Berlin traced positive liberty from Aristotle's definition of citizenship, which is historically derived from the social role of the freemen of classical Athens: it was, Berlin argued, the liberty in choosing their government granted to citizens, and extolled, most famously, by [[Pericles]]. Berlin granted that both concepts of liberty represent valid human ideals, and that both forms of liberty are necessary in any free and civilised society.{{citation needed|date=August 2012}} === Negative liberty === :"liberty in the negative sense involves an answer to the question: 'What is the area within which the subject—a person or group of persons—is or should be left to do or be what he is able to do or be, without interference by other persons'."Berlin, I: "Two Concepts of Liberty",1958 For Berlin, [[negative liberty]] represents a different, and sometimes contradictory, understanding of the concept of liberty, which needs to be carefully examined. Its later proponents (such as [[Tocqueville]], [[Benjamin Constant|Constant]], [[Montesquieu]], [[John Locke]], [[David Hume]] and [[John Stuart Mill]],{{citation needed|date=June 2013}} who accepted [[Chrysippus]]' understanding of [[self-determination]])Isaiah Berlin, (Oxford 2004) ''Liberty'', page 171 and 260 insisted that constraint and discipline were the antithesis of liberty and so were (and are) less prone to confusing liberty and constraint in the manner of rationalists and the philosophical harbingers of totalitarianism.{{citation needed|date=June 2013}} This concept of negative liberty, Berlin argued, constitutes an alternative, and sometimes even opposed, concept to positive liberty, and one often closer to the intuitive modern usage of the word. Berlin considered negative liberty one of the distinguishing concepts of modern liberalism and observed :"The fathers of liberalism--Mill and Constant--want more than this minimum: they demand a maximum degree of non-interference compatible with the minimum demands of social life. It seems unlikely that this extreme demand for liberty has ever been made by any but a small minority of highly civilized and self-conscious human beings."Berlin, I: "Two Concepts of Liberty",1958 === Abuse of positive liberty === Isaiah Berlin notes that historically positive liberty has proven particularly susceptible to rhetorical abuse; especially from the 18th century onwards, it has either been paternalistically re-drawn from the third-person, or conflated with the concept of negative liberty and thus disguised underlying value-conflicts. Berlin contended that under the influence of [[Plato]], [[Aristotle]], [[Jean-Jacques Rousseau]], [[Immanuel Kant]], and [[G. W. F. Hegel]], modern political thinkers often conflated positive liberty with rational action, based upon a rational knowledge to which, it is argued, only a certain elite or social group has access.Isaiah Bern, (Oxford 2004) ''Liberty'', page 257 This rationalist conflation was open to political abuses, which encroached on negative liberty, when such interpretations of positive liberty were, in the nineteenth century, used to defend nationalism, paternalism, social engineering, historicism, and collective rational control over human destiny. Berlin argued that, following this line of thought, demands for freedom paradoxically could become demands for forms of collective control and discipline—those deemed necessary for the "self-mastery" or "self-determination" of nations, classes, democratic communities, and even humanity as a whole. There is thus an elective affinity, for Berlin, between positive liberty, when it is rhetorically conflated with goals imposed from the third-person that the individual is told they "should" rationally desire, and the justifications for political [[totalitarianism]], which contrary to [[value-pluralism]], presupposed that values exist in [[Pythagoreanism|Pythagorean]] harmony. {{citation needed|date=June 2013}} === Dialectic of positive and negative liberty === Berlin did not argue that the concept of positive liberty should be rejected—on the contrary, he recognised it as one human value among many, and one necessary to any free society.Four Essays on Liberty, Oxford University Press, 1969. Superseded by Liberty. He argued that positive liberty was a genuine and valuable version of liberty, so long as it was identified with the autonomy of individuals, and not with the achievement of goals that individuals 'ought to' 'rationally' desire.Isaiah Berlin, (Oxford 2004) ''Liberty'', p 39 Berlin argued, rather, that these differing concepts showed the plurality, and incompatibility of human values, and the need to analytically distinguish and trade-off between, rather than conflate, them.Isaiah Berlin, (Oxford 2004) ''Liberty'', page 217 Thus, Berlin offers in his "Two Concepts of Liberty" essay, "Where it is to be drawn is a matter of argument, indeed of haggling. Men are largely interdependent, and no man's activity is so completely private as never to obstruct the lives of others in any way. 'Freedom for the pike is death for the minnows'; the liberty of some must depend on the restraint of others. Freedom for an Oxford don, others have been known to add, is a very different thing from freedom for an Egyptian peasant." == See also == * [[Positive and negative rights]] == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20180131015207/http://faculty.www.umb.edu/steven.levine/courses/Fall%202015/What%20is%20Freedom%20Writings/Berlin.pdf "Two Concepts of Liberty"] * [http://berlin.wolf.ox.ac.uk/ The Isaiah Berlin Virtual Library] * {{cite SEP |url-id=liberty-positive-negative |title=Positive and Negative Liberty |last=Carter |first=Ian}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2011}} [[Category:1958 speeches]] [[Category:Books in political philosophy]] [[Category:Pamphlets]] [[Category:Human rights concepts]]

Biên phòng Việt Nam }}) is branch of the [[Vietnam People's Army]], as the core, responsible management and protection of the sovereignty, territorial integrity, security, order and national boundaries on the mainland, islands, sea and at the gate as shall by law and is a force members in provincial areas of defence, border districts of the [[Socialist Republic of Vietnam]].{{cite web|url=http://www.bienphongvietnam.vn/cnnh.vt |accessdate=13 December 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100913012045/http://www.bienphongvietnam.vn/cnnh.vt |archivedate=13 September 2010 }} ==Origins== On 19 November 1958, the [[Politburo of the Communist Party of Vietnam]] decided to unite national defence forces and army units whose missions were domestic protection, border protection, beach defence, boundary security, and other forces in charge of guarding domestic international borders, under the management of the Police Department, and named them the ''Guard forces''. Guard forces including Border Guard and Homeland Guard.[[:vi:Bộ đội Biên phòng Việt Nam|Bộ đội Biên phòng Việt Nam – Wikipedia tiếng Việt]], Retrieved 4 March 2012{{Better source|reason=per WP:CIRCULAR|date=August 2015}} According to the resolution of the Politburo, Border Guard is responsible for: * Opportune repress spies, commandos, bandits, sea pirates and small cliques other destructive activities in cross-border, border, coast; * Heavily attack on any army infringe upon national borders, to cope with all activities of war while waiting for the army come to reinforce; * Prevent and punish smugglers on border areas; * Implementing regulations on cross-border promulgated by the government of [[Socialist Republic of Vietnam]] and control of cross-border traffic (including cars, people, baggage, goods, works and cultural objects from other users in Vietnam brought out abroad and brought into Vietnam); * Safety protect people's life and property and the State's property, the treasure, cooperatives, public schools, farms, in the border areas, against bandits, sea pirates, rangers surprised attack. Homeland Guard is responsible for (this task transferred to police protection under the General Department of Police, Ministry of Public Security): * Suppress all destructive activities of the small fee, parachuting spies and violence, destruction of the other counter-revolutionary cliques; * Protect the headquarters, the leader of the Party and State, the diplomatic missions, international leaders and foreign guests visiting to Vietnam; * Protect factories, mines, warehouses important, the centre of important contact information, clues and important transport axis, and an important transport, cultural facilities, science and Art is important; * Protect Capital, cities and towns is important, protecting the rallies by the central government regulations, executive orders curfew as needed and the people's police to maintain order general security; * Guarding the camps, prisons, escorting political prisoners and criminal matter, the hearing protection. On 3 March 1959, the [[Prime Minister of Vietnam]] signed Decision No. 100 - TTg on the establishment of an armed force in charge of border protection and domestic, to be known as the People's Armed Police, set under the leadership of the Ministry of Public Security. This date is taken as the date of establishment of the Vietnam Border Defence Force. Ceremony set up the People's Armed Police was held on the evening of 28 March 1959, at 19 hours, at the Military Club, Hanoi. By the end of 1979 the People's Armed Police was renamed Border Defence Force and transferred under the [[Ministry of Defence (Vietnam)]]. In 1988, the Border Defence Force moved to directly under the Ministry of Interior until late in 1995, then moved to the [[Ministry of Defence (Vietnam)]]. ==Mission== Border Defence Force is the core force in charge, in co-ordination with other armed forces, localities and departments concerned and depend on people to manage, protect borders, maintaining security political, social order and safety in the border areas, maintaining the external border. Border Defence Force operates under the laws of the [[Vietnam|Socialist Republic of Vietnam]], the international treaties relating to the sovereignty, national security and border on the mainland, islands, seas and border gates that the Socialist Republic of Vietnam has signed or acceded to. ==Structure== The organisational system of Border Defence Force includes three levels: Command (Central), Command provinces; Border posts. '''Command of Border Defence Force''' * General Staff * Political Department * Department of Logistics * Technology and Equipment Department * Department of Reconnaissance * Department of Drug Prevention * Border Crossings Department * Office of the Command * 21st Information Regiment * Border Defence Force Academy * Border Defence Force School '''Border Command of the Provinces and [[Municipalities of Vietnam]]''' '''Border posts''' * Border Defence Force Squadrons * Border Defence Force Flotillas ==Ranks== {| style="border:1px solid #8888aa; background:#f7f8ff; padding:5px; font-size:100%; margin:0 12px 12px 0; width:100%;" |- style="background:lightsteelblue;" ! {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = [[The Right Honourable]] | name = The Lord Haughey | honorific_suffix = [[Order of the British Empire|OBE]] | image = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1956|7|2|df=y}}<ref name="ET"/> | birth_place = [[Gorbals]],<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b039gj3b |title=Schemes and dreams: Big Specky Haughey |date=15 September 2013 |accessdate=27 March 2018 |publisher=[[BBC Radio Scotland]]}}</ref> [[Glasgow]], Scotland | occupation = [[Chairperson|Chairman]], City Refrigeration Holdings UK Ltd |networth = {{increase}} [[Pound sterling|£]]252 million |party = [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] | spouse = {{marriage|[http://www.williehaughey.com/willie-haughey-family.aspx Susan Haughey, ''née'' Moore] |1978}} | children = [http://www.williehaughey.com/willie-haughey-family.aspx Kenny Haughey] }} '''William Haughey, Baron Haughey''', [[Order of the British Empire|OBE]] (born 1956 in [[Glasgow]])<ref>[http://www.pressteam.co.uk/index.php/news/tycoon-unveils-house-plans PressTeam Scotland Ltd - Tycoon unveils house plans<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> is a Scottish [[businessman]], [[philanthropist]]<ref name="ET"/> and [[chairperson|chairman]] of City Facilities Management Holdings Ltd.
==Career== Haughey had attended [[Holyrood Secondary School]]<ref name=early/> followed by [[Langside College]],<ref name=insiderprofile/> and then worked in the [[refrigeration]] and [[air conditioning]] industry in [[Abu Dhabi]] before returning to Scotland to set up his own business with £70,000 of savings he had accrued. He founded City Refrigeration, a refrigeration equipment and maintenance supplier, with his wife Susan in 1985.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-scotland-business-22988889 | work=BBC News | title=Sir Willie Haughey's City Refrigeration sees profits up | date=20 June 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.cityfm.com/about-city/ | publisher=City Facilities Management | title=About City | accessdate=27 March 2018}}</ref>
[[File:Caledonia House (geograph 3220465).jpg|left|thumb|City Facilities Management headquarters in [[Glasgow]]]] After securing a service contract with the [[Wellpark Brewery|Tennent's]] company in the 1980s which led to agreements with further breweries, he sold a majority stake to the [[3i]] equity firm.<ref name=insiderprofile/> A downturn in the financial situation caused Haughey to sell two other small companies he had established back to City to increase turnover and broaden the range of services provided by the firm. In 1997 the firm signed a deal with [[Asda]] to maintain refrigeration equipment in stores throughout the United Kingdom. Due to the success of that venture, Haughey and his wife found themselves able to buy back almost full control of City from 3i in 1999,<ref name=stroke/> allowing them to have decisive input on its future strategic direction;<ref name=insiderprofile/> a gradual, continuous expansion of its operations followed over the subsequent decades.<ref name=stroke>{{cite web |url=http://www.williehaughey.com:80/city-refrigeration-expands.aspx|title=Stroke Of Genius|publisher=Willie Haughey: An Inspirational Scottish Businessman|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121102234903/http://www.williehaughey.com:80/city-refrigeration-expands.aspx|archive-date=2 November 2012|date=|accessdate=6 April 2018}}</ref>
Haughey backed the [[Entrepreneurial Spark]] start-up accelerator, hosting the Glasgow 'hatchery' in his City Refrigeration Headquarters.<ref name=insiderprofile>{{cite news|url=https://www.insider.co.uk/special-reports/big-profile-blast-past-sir-10795465|title=The Big Profile Blast from the Past: Sir Willie Haughey, City Refrigerations Holdings|work=Scottish Business Insider|publisher=[[Trinity Mirror]]|date=1 May 2013|accessdate=6 April 2018}}</ref>
The City corporate headquarters are at ''Caledonia House'' in [[Gorbals]], Glasgow, having relocated from nearby [[Shawfield]] in 2009 when those premises were demolished for construction of the [[A74(M) and M74 motorways#M74 northern extension to M8 (2008–2011)|M74 motorway completion]].<ref name=insiderprofile/> The new site was virtually on the site of Haughey's childhood home which had been demolished years earlier.<ref name=early>{{cite web|url=http://www.williehaughey.com:80/city-refrigeration-early.aspx|title=The Early Years|publisher=Willie Haughey: An Inspirational Scottish Businessman|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120614163553/http://www.williehaughey.com:80/city-refrigeration-early.aspx|archive-date=14 June 2012|date=|accessdate=6 April 2018}}</ref> The technical division is located in Clydesmill Industrial Estate near to [[Cambuslang]].
By 2017, the company had been rebranded as ''City Facilities Management'' and launched a European arm, headquartered in [[Paris]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.insider.co.uk/news/sir-willie-haugheys-city-refrigeration-10814391|title=Sir Willie Haughey's City Refrigeration Holdings launched new European venture|work=Scottish Business Insider|publisher=[[Trinity Mirror]]|date=17 July 2017|accessdate=6 April 2018}}</ref> Their international clients include [[Coles Supermarkets]] in Australia.<ref name=insiderprofile/>
==Personal life and awards== Haughey married Susan in 1978. He has one son Kenny.<ref name=insiderprofile/> In his spare time he enjoys playing golf and tournament poker. He once revealed that he winds down every Friday night with a [[fish supper]].<ref name="ET">{{cite web|title=I may be a millionaire but there's nothing I like better than a fish supper on a Friday night|url=http://www.eveningtimes.co.uk/news/12849417.I_may_be_a_millionaire_but_there_apos_s_nothing_I_like_better_than_a_fish_supper_on_a_Friday_night/|publisher=''[[Evening Times]]''|accessdate=16 January 2017|date=3 October 2007}}</ref>
He is a [[Celtic F.C.]] season ticket holder and was formerly a non-executive director of the club.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/12327452.Five_hour_Celtic_boardroom_row_as_Haughey_quits/ |title=Five-hour Celtic boardroom row as Haughey quits|date=30 April 1997|accessdate=27 March 2018 |work=The Herald}}</ref> He was close friends with former Celtic player [[Jimmy Johnstone]] before his death,<ref name="ET"/><ref name=broke/><ref name=giant>{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/default_content/12375771.Memories_of_a_giant_wee_man/|title=Memories of a giant wee man|work=[[The Herald (Scotland)|The Herald]]|date=13 December 2008 |accessdate=22 May 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/scottish-news/jimmy-johnstones-family-reveal-struggle-8856250|title=Jimmy Johnstone's family reveal his struggle after being let go by Jock Stein at Celtic|work=Daily Record|date=18 September 2016|accessdate=22 May 2018}}</ref> and is a collector of club memorabilia,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.glasgowlive.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/gold-replica-european-cup-won-11414296|title=Gold replica of the European Cup won by Celtic in 1967 bought for £58k at auction|date=1 June 2016|accessdate=27 March 2018 |work=Glasgow Live}}</ref><ref name=broke>{{cite news |url=https://www.thescottishsun.co.uk/news/1764931/celtic-frank-mcavennie-medals-football-career/|title=Celtic hero Frank McAvennie broke down after Scots tycoon handed back medals he flogged at lowest point|date=28 October 2017|accessdate=27 March 2018 |work=The Scottish Sun}}</ref> much of which (including the medal collections of Johnstone and [[Tommy Gemmell]]) he has loaned back to Celtic for display in their museum.<ref name=lionheart>{{cite book|last1=McColl|first1=Graham|last2=Gemmell|first2=Tommy|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=v4_p_JPA8KgC&pg=PT184&lpg=PT184&dq=%22jimmy+johnstone%22+%22willie+haughey%22&source=bl&ots=FKip85WD7l&sig=4nOFCq4KmK2Y0AxgiwpK2Q-aT-k&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiZ99f7opnbAhURLFAKHfo1C-k4FBDoAQhYMAg#v=onepage&q=%22jimmy%20johnstone%22%20%22willie%20haughey%22&f=false|title=Tommy Gemmell: Lion Heart|year=2012|publisher=Random House|isbn=9781448132454}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/12266783.Lisbon_Lion_selling_his_coveted_winner_apos_s_medal/|title=Lisbon Lion selling his coveted winner's medal|date=2 September 1999|accessdate=27 March 2018 |work=The Herald}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/local-news/cambuslang-businessman-ensures-willie-maley-9983052 |title=Cambuslang businessman ensures Willie Maley medals will remain at Celtic Park|date=8 March 2017|accessdate=27 March 2018 |work=Daily Record / [[Rutherglen Reformer]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.celticfc.net/news/10633|title=Rare Celtic artefacts returned to Paradise |date=2 June 2016|accessdate=27 March 2018 |publisher=Celtic F.C.}}</ref>
[[File:P houston (cup).jpg|right|thumb|Haughey provided the sponsorship funds for the 'Active Nation Scottish Cup' in [[2009–10 Scottish Cup|2010]]]] He also provided £2 million in funding to the [[Scottish Cup]] while the tournament did not have a main sponsor between 2008 and 2010,<ref name=charitable/> with the [[Scottish Government]] allowed to use the 'branding space' competition to promote their [[Homecoming Scotland 2009]]<ref name=giant/><ref name="Homecoming_BBC">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/scot_cups/7659053.stm|title=Homecoming Scottish Cup Unveiled|date=14 October 2008|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=11 January 2008}}</ref> and ''Active Nation''<ref name="activenation">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/scot_cups/8266911.stm|title=Scottish Cup given new branding|date=21 September 2009|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=21 September 2009}}</ref> initiatives.
He is a huge [[Oasis (band)|Oasis]] fan{{cn|date=March 2018}} and has confessed to liking 80s band [[A-ha]] after a City employee offered him free tickets to an A-ha concert during the band's 2010 farewell tour.
Haughey gave over £5 million to charity over a five year period.<ref name=charitable>{{cite web|url=http://www.williehaughey.com/city-charitable-trust.aspx|title=City Charitable Trust|publisher=Willie Haughey: An Inspirational Scottish Businessman|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120912042755/http://www.williehaughey.com:80/city-charitable-trust.aspx|archive-date=12 September 2012|date=|accessdate=6 April 2018}}</ref> In January 2011 Haughey presented a cheque for £100,000 to UNICEF ambassador Sir Alex Ferguson to support the charity’s work with child flood victims in Pakistan.<ref>http://www.beattiegroup.com/prclients/pr-press-releases.aspx?news=31&id=10839</ref><ref>http://www.unicef.org.uk/Latest/News/Willie-Haughey/</ref> In 2010 alone, he made charitable donations of £1.3 million.<ref name=charitable/>
He was awarded an [[Order of the British Empire|OBE]] in 2003<ref>{{London Gazette |issue=56963 |date=14 June 2003 |page=11 |supp=y}}</ref> and was [[Knight bachelor|knighted]] in the [[2012 Birthday Honours]] for services to business and philanthropy.<ref>{{London Gazette |issue=60173 |date=16 June 2012 |page=1 |supp=y}}</ref><ref>{{London Gazette |issue=60593 |date=9 August 2013 |page=15796}}</ref> On 1 August 2013, it was announced he was going to be a [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] peer in the [[House of Lords]].
Haughey has been named in several newspaper reports in connection with the resignation of [[Steven Purcell]], the leader of [[Glasgow City Council]] until 2010.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.scotsman.com/comment/Eddie-Barnes-Resignation-is-a.6117742.jp|title=Resignation is a hammer-blow for Scottish Labour so close to a general election|date=3 March 2010|publisher=The Scotsman|accessdate=28 March 2010|location=Edinburgh}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://scotlandonsunday.scotsman.com/comment/Steven-Purcell-Fall-of-a.6130367.jp|title=Steven Purcell: Fall of a High Flier|date=7 March 2010|publisher=Scotland on Sunday|accessdate=28 March 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/politics/article7061166.ece|title=Labour donor Willie Haughey in ‘cash for favours’ row|date=14 March 2010|publisher=Sunday Times Scotland|accessdate=28 March 2010 | location=London | first1=Jon | last1=Ungoed-Thomas | first2=Mark | last2=MacAskill}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/politics/company-linked-to-purcell-in-700-000-land-deal-with-labour-donor-1.1014924|title=Company linked to Purcell in £700,000 land deal with Labour donor|date=21 March 2010|publisher=The Herald|accessdate=28 March 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/politics/firm-caught-up-in-purcell-furore-pulls-out-of-labour-party-conference-1.1015284|title=Firm caught up in Purcell furore pulls out of Labour party conference|date=23 March 2010|publisher=The Herald|accessdate=28 March 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.economist.com/world/britain/displaystory.cfm?story_id=15772731|title=Heartland attack|date=25 March 2010|publisher=[[The Economist]]|accessdate=28 March 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/scotland/article7078926.ece|title=Labour in little local difficulty|date=28 March 2010|publisher=Sunday Times Scotland|accessdate=28 March 2010 | location=London | first=Mark | last=MacAskill}}</ref>
In 2011, Haughey had planning permission for the conversion of Greenleeshill Farm,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://hawthorneboyle.co.uk/projects/large-detached-houses/greenleeshill-house-greenleeshill-farm-cambuslang/ |title=Greenleeshill Farm, Cambuslang |date= |accessdate=27 March 2018 |publisher=Hawthorne Boyle Ltd}}</ref> situated on [[Green belt|greenbelt]] land in [[South Lanarkshire]], with panoramic views over Glasgow<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.scotsman.com/news/fridge-tycoon-gets-go-ahead-for-new-home-after-earlier-cold-shoulder-from-planners-1-1498410 |title=Fridge tycoon gets go-ahead for new home after earlier cold shoulder from planners |date=25 January 2011 |accessdate=27 March 2018 |work=[[The Scotsman]]}}</ref> into a [[mansion]] resembling the [[White House]] US presidential residence.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.scotsman.com/news/tycoon-aims-to-make-his-white-house-the-country-s-finest-home-1-702699 |title=Tycoon aims to make his 'White House' the country's finest home |date=6 December 2007 |accessdate=27 March 2018 |work=The Scotsman}}</ref>
On 18 September 2013 he was created a [[life peer]] taking the title '''Baron Haughey''', of [[Hutchesontown]] in the City of [[Glasgow]].<ref>{{London Gazette |issue=60635 |date=23 September 2013 |page=18709}}</ref>
The 2017 edition of the [[Sunday Times Rich List]] estimated his family's fortune at £265 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nuk-rich-list-ui-2017-uk-prod.eu-west-1.elasticbeanstalk.com/richlist/view/group17|title=Rich list 2017 - Wealthiest in Scotland|work=[[The Sunday Times]]|date=|accessdate=6 April 2018}}</ref>
In 2018, Haughey was reported as having become involved in discussions between the [[Scottish Football Association]] and [[Queen's Park F.C.]] over the future use of [[Hampden Park]], the stadium used by the former but owned by the latter. With the SFA threatening to move their matches to [[Edinburgh]] and unwilling to pay more than £2 million to buy Hampden from Queen's Park while the club demanded £6 million, Haughey stepped in with an offer to 'split the difference' by adding a contribution to raise the purchase offer to £4 million, in order for [[Scotland national football team|Scotland]] matches and cup finals to remain in their traditional Glasgow home.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.scotsman.com/sport/football/teams/scotland/scottish-fa-close-to-4m-purchase-of-hampden-park-reports-1-4797517 |title=Scottish FA close to £4m purchase of Hampden Park - reports |date=10 September 2018 |accessdate=11 September 2018 |work=The Scotsman}}</ref>

'''Youth unemployment in Italy''' discusses the statistics, trends, causes and consequences concerning the topic of unemployment among young Italians.
According to the [[European Union]]’s standards, youth unemployment refers to people of age between 15 and 24. [[Italy]] displays one of the highest rates of youth unemployment among the 35 member countries of the [[OECD|Organization of Economic Co-Operation and Development]] (OECD).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.repubblica.it/economia/miojob/lavoro/2017/10/10/news/ocse_l_italia_e_il_terzo_posto_peggiore_per_i_giovani_che_cercano_lavoro-177863595/?refresh_ce|title=Ocse, l'Italia è il terzo posto peggiore per i giovani che cercano lavoro|last=|first=|date=|website=La Repubblica.it|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=December 7, 2017}}</ref> The Italian youth unemployment rate started raising dramatically since the [[Financial crisis of 2007–2008|2008 financial crisis]] reaching its peak of 42.67% in 2014.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://data.oecd.org/unemp/youth-unemployment-rate.htm|title=Youth unemployment rate|last=|first=|date=|website=OECD|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=December 7, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.repubblica.it/economia/2015/04/29/news/il_lavoro_negli_anni_della_crisi_l_italia_paga_il_conto_la_disoccupazione_e_cresciuta_del_108_-112996138/|title=Il lavoro negli anni della crisi: l'Italia paga il conto, la disoccupazione è cresciuta del 108%|last=|first=|date=|website=Repubblica.it|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=December 7, 2017}}</ref> In 2017, among the EU member states, the youth unemployment rate of Italy (35.1%) was exceeded by only [[Spain]] and [[Greece]]. The Italian youth unemployment rate was more than the double of the total EU average rate of 16.7% in 2017.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.statista.com/statistics/266228/youth-unemployment-rate-in-eu-countries/|title=Youth unemployment rate in Europe (EU member states) as of August 2017|last=|first=|date=|website=Statista|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=December 7, 2017}}</ref> While youth unemployment is extremely high compared to EU standards, the Italian total unemployment rate (11.1%) is closer to EU average (7.4%).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/statistics-explained/index.php/File:Unemployment_rates,_seasonally_adjusted,_October_2017_(%25)_F2.png|title=Unemployment rates, seasonally adjusted, October 2017 (%)|last=|first=|date=|website=Eurostat|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=December 7, 2017}}</ref> == Statistics == [[Youth unemployment]] in Italy is quantified by many measures. According to EU statistics, 10.6% of all Italian 15–24 year-olds were unemployed in 2015.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/tgm/table.do?tab=table&init=1&language=en&pcode=tespm080&plugin=1|title=Youth unemployment ratio (15-24)|last=|first=|date=|website=Eurostat|publisher=European Commission|access-date=2016-11-21}}</ref> Comparatively, in the [[European Union]] 28 the rate that year was 8.4%.<ref name=":0" /> These levels are deceptively low because they include both active and inactive youth, which counts students and those not looking for work. Leaving out the inactive population, 40.3% of 15–24 year-olds who were actively part of the [[labor force]] were unemployed in 2015.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/tgm/table.do?tab=table&init=1&language=en&pcode=tipslm80&plugin=1|title=Youth unemployment rate - % of active population aged 15-24|last=|first=|date=|website=Eurostat|publisher=European Commission|access-date=2016-11-21}}</ref> 22% of the same population had been unemployed for 12 or more months, meaning more than half of the unemployed active Italian youth had been so long-term.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=yth_empl_120&lang=en|title=Youth long-term unemployment rate (12 months or longer) by sex and age|last=|first=|date=|website=Eurostat|publisher=European Commission|access-date=2016-11-21}}</ref> Yet another subset of the youth population is neither in employment nor in education and training (NEET), which in 2015 represented 21.4% of Italy's 15–24 year-olds.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/tgm/table.do?tab=table&init=1&language=en&pcode=tesem150&plugin=1|title=Youth neither in employment nor in education and training (NEET) rate, age group 15-24|last=|first=|date=|website=Eurostat|publisher=European Commission|access-date=2016-11-21}}</ref> In addition to complete unemployment, Italian youth also have high levels of [[underemployment]]. The number of 15–24 year-olds who worked full-time (30 hours per week) dropped from 1,597,000 in 2000 to 676,000 in 2015, while the number of [[part-time worker]]s increased from 172,000 to 237,000 people.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://stats.oecd.org/|title=FTPT employment based on a common definition|last=|first=|date=|website=OECD.Stat|publisher=Organisation for Economic Co-Operation and Development|access-date=2016-11-21}}</ref> Furthermore, 83.7% of the young part-time workers in 2015 did so involuntarily because they could not find full-time employment.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=yth_empl_080&lang=en|title=Involuntary part-time employment as percentage of the total part-time employment for young people by sex and age|last=|first=|date=|website=Eurostat|publisher=European Commission|access-date=2016-11-21}}</ref>
== Causes ==
=== Welfare system and labor market policy === From a structural perspective, Italy's problem of youth [[unemployment]] is caused by its [[protectionist]] welfare system and [[labor market]]. In 2015, 62.4% 15–24 year-olds who were registered unemployed for 6–11 months did not receive any benefits or assistance; the same rate measured in the population of 15–74 year-olds was 52.4%.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/submitViewTableAction.do|title=Unemployment by sex, age, duration of unemployment and distinction registration/benefits (%)|last=|first=|date=|website=Eurostat|publisher=European Commission|access-date=2016-11-27}}</ref> Though this demonstrates that benefits are exclusive for people of all ages in Italy, the young unemployed are left out at a rate 10% higher than the general population. This can be attributed to the country's [[corporatist]] structure; similarly to Greece, Spain, and Portugal (grouped into the "Southern Model" of European welfare) benefits in Italy are distributed in a very fragmented manner according to occupation.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Ferrera|first=Maurizio|date=1996-02-01|title=The 'Southern Model' of Welfare in Social Europe|url=http://esp.sagepub.com/content/6/1/17|journal=Journal of European Social Policy|language=en|volume=6|issue=1|pages=17–37|doi=10.1177/095892879600600102|issn=0958-9287}}</ref> There are separate benefit schemes, or "micro-schemes", for specific private and public sectors, types of self-employment, and the large group of industrial workers called INPS.<ref name=":1" /> This system is split into the core group of labor market insiders receives generous benefits (such as pensions), while the irregular workers receive minimal benefits.<ref name=":1" /> For example, upon retirement an institutional worker would receive a pension of 89% their average net earnings, but a non-institutional worker would receive only 19%.<ref name=":1" /> Paradoxically, this "economic protection" model makes it difficult for young people to get their first job because they have never been part of the labor market.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Cinalli|first=Manlio|last2=Giugni|first2=Marco|date=2013-07-01|title=New challenges for the welfare state: The emergence of youth unemployment regimes in Europe?|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/ijsw.12016/abstract|journal=International Journal of Social Welfare|language=en|volume=22|issue=3|pages=290–299|doi=10.1111/ijsw.12016|issn=1468-2397}}</ref> To illustrate, the unemployment benefits given to an Italian 18 year-old who has never had a job is 0% of average net earnings.<ref name=":1" /> In addition to receiving nonexistent/minimal benefits, a study also found youth were excluded based on factors including: the prerequisites for coverage, the age coverage is extended to, and sanctions for incorrectly using the system.<ref name=":2" /> Italy's model has exclusive unemployment benefits coupled with inflexible labor market policy (which means workers have high employment protection and are unlikely to be fired), which creates inhospitable conditions for young people seeking jobs.<ref name=":2" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.oecd.org/els/emp/oecdindicatorsofemploymentprotection.htm|title=OECD Indicators of Employment Protection - OECD|website=www.oecd.org|access-date=2016-11-28}}</ref>
=== Tertiary education system === Italy's [[university]] system is another force driving youth unemployment. In 2005, the gap between finishing school and obtaining employment 51.3 months, much higher than the EU average of 30 months.<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Pastore|first=Francesco|year=2012|title=Youth Unemployment in Italy at the Time of the New Great Depression|url=http://www.youthpolicy.org/library/documents/youth-unemployment-in-italy-at-the-time-of-the-new-great-depression/|journal=Friedrerich Ebert Stiftung|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> Though 75% of Italian students earn a high school diploma that qualifies them to enter a university (one of the highest levels out of the OECD countries), only 70% of those students actually enroll in a university.<ref name=":3" /> Of those who do attend a university, the educational system leaves them unprepared for the labor market. One reason is that students do not have contact with the labor market and do not gain work experience; 26.1% of unemployed youth have zero work experience, and until recently universities did not even have career services to connect students to job opportunities.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":4">{{Cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2013-06-09/la-dolce-vita-eludes-italian-students-found-unemployable|title=La Dolce Vita Eludes Italian Students Found Unemployable|last=Staley|first=Oliver|date=2013-06-09|newspaper=Bloomberg.com|access-date=2016-11-29}}</ref> Courses generally do not involve practical application of the subject and there are not many educational internships.<ref name=":4" /> Another characteristic of the Italian university system is that students take an extended amount of time to finish their degrees (for instance, students are allowed to retake their final exams up to six times).<ref name=":4" /> Graduates are then overqualified for the labor market, meaning they have a higher skill level than what is in demand (called a vertical mismatch).<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/statistics-explained/index.php/Employment_rates_of_recent_graduates|title=Employment rates of recent graduates - Statistics Explained|website=ec.europa.eu|access-date=2016-11-29}}</ref> This forces university graduates to take jobs usually reserved for people with lower skill levels, such as those with secondary education or other post-secondary training.<ref name=":5" /> Young non-university graduates then experience higher rates of unemployment (45%) than their degree-holding counterparts (25.6%).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=edat_lfse_25&lang=en|title=Unemployment rates of young people not in education and training by sex, educational attainment level and years since completion of highest level of education|last=|first=|date=|website=Eurostat|publisher=European Commission|access-date=2016-11-28}}</ref>
== Consequences ==
=== Emigration === In the last years, the media in Italy increasingly addresses the issue of the international migration flows of young people as a phenomenon of [[Human capital flight|brain drain.]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://bruegel.org/2014/03/the-global-race-for-talent-europes-migration-challenge/|title=The global race for talent: Europe’s migration challenge|last=Münz|first=Rainer|date=2014|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=December 7, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.corriere.it/scuola/studiare-e-lavorare-all-estero/notizie/se-ne-vanno-giovani-laureati-nostra-vita-genitori-nell-italia-figli-lontani-3ab07376-9c5f-11e7-9e5e-7cf41a352984.shtml|title=Se ne vanno giovani e laureati: la nostra vita di genitori nell’Italia dei figli lontani|last=|first=|date=|website=Corriere.it|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=December 7, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ilsole24ore.com/art/notizie/2017-07-06/oltre-250000-italiani-emigrano-all-estero-erano-300000-dopoguerra-094053.shtml?uuid=AEuX6nsB|title=Oltre 250mila italiani emigrano all’estero, quasi quanti nel Dopoguerra|last=Carli|first=Andrea|date=2017|website=Il Sole 24 ORE|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=December 7, 2017}}</ref> The high rate of unemployment encourages young citizens to leave the country. In fact, the main reason of the high numbers of young people leaving the country is the prospect of job opportunities abroad.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ilfattoquotidiano.it/2015/09/12/lavoro-il-61-dei-giovani-italiani-pronto-a-emigrare-per-cercarlo-allestero/2029721/|title=Lavoro, “il 61% dei giovani italiani pronto a emigrare per cercarlo all’estero”|last=|first=|date=|website=Il Fatto Quotidiano|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=December 7, 2017}}</ref> Youth emigration as a consequence results in the Italian government losing its investments in education and a considerable amount of young labor force.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The New Southern European Diaspora : Youth, Unemployment, and Migration|last=Ricucci|first=Roberta|publisher=Lexington Books|year=2017|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> In the majority of the cases, the young unemployed emigrate in either other countries of the EU (mainly the [[United Kingdom]] and [[Germany]]) or in the [[United States]] and [[Australia]]. In 2016, more than 39% of Italian emigrants were of age between 18 and 34. Additionally, the percentage of young Italian emigrants is increasing every year at a steady rate.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ilfattoquotidiano.it/2017/10/17/italiani-allestero-nel-2016-emigrati-in-124mila-il-39-ha-tra-i-18-e-i-34-anni-regno-unito-meta-preferita/3918408/|title=Italiani all’estero, nel 2016 emigrati in 124mila: il 39% ha tra i 18 e i 34 anni. Regno Unito meta preferita|last=|first=|date=|website=Il Fatto Quotidiano|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=December 7, 2017}}</ref>
== North-South Division == It is often argued that Italy is made up of two different economies, one belonging to the North and one to the South.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.economist.com/news/finance-and-economics/21651261-north-limps-ahead-south-swoons-tale-two-economies|title=Italy’s regional divide: A tale of two economies|last=|first=|date=|website=The Economist|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=December 7, 2017}}</ref> In terms of youth unemployment, there is a regional divide between North and South within Italy. In 2016, Italy presented one of the most internally diverse regional unemployment rates among the EU member states (together with other Southern European countries such as [[Greece]] and [[Spain]]). More than half of the young population was unemployed in the southern regions of Italy ([[Calabria]], [[Campania]], [[Apulia|Puglia]] and [[Sicily|Sicilia]]). More precisely, the youth unemployment rates of Calabria reached an historical European peak of 58.7% in 2016.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ansa.it/sito/notizie/economia/2017/04/27/disoccupati-sud-italia-doppio-media-ue_bca1ebab-3952-4b15-8a02-334f1aaa5cdf.html|title=Calabria al top Ue per disoccupazione giovanile|last=|first=|date=|website=Ansa.it|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=December 7, 2017}}</ref> On the other hand, unemployment rates in the northern regions (such as [[Lombardy|Lombardia]], [[Piedmont|Piemonte]] and [[Veneto]]) varied between 5% and 10%.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/statistics-explained/index.php/Labour_market_statistics_at_regional_level|title=Labour market statistics at regional level|last=|first=|date=|website=Eurostat|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=December 7, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/documents/3217494/5786257/KS-HA-14-001-04-EN.PDF/6e76839c-650e-43d9-80f8-ca12da933f07|title=Labour Market|last=|first=|date=|website=Eurostat|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=December 7, 2017}}</ref>
